No philosophical background is required. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 333 or PHIL 433.

PHIL 334.description: Relationship between sex, gender, and philosophy. Topics may include ethics, epistemology, science, social relations, law, and personhood.

PHIL 335.description: Philosophical approaches to historical problems of inequality and social harm, with readings drawn from historical and contemporary sources. Topics to be studied may include slavery, colonialism, labour, and the position of women in society.

PHIL 338.description: Concepts of law, constitution and sovereignty; law and morality; natural law theories and legal positivism; obligation, responsibility, and punishment.

PHIL 339.description: Topics include art and perception, art and reality, imagination, expression, censorship, and the role of art in human life.

PHIL 340.description: Topics in metaphysics such as the nature of physical reality, personal identity, the mind/body problem, free will, causation and action theory. Readings from classic and contemporary texts.

PHIL 347.description: A critical and analytical examination of arguments for and arguments against the existence of God, and other related topics. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 347 or PHIL 349.

PHIL 348.description: Major themes and figures in the Continental philosophy tradition; possible topics include 19th century precursors, 20th century philosophers, and comparisons between analytic and continental philosophy.

PHIL 360.description: An examination of historical, conceptual and methodological conditions of scientific knowledge through detailed consideration of important episodes in the history of science.
PHIL 360.longname: Introduction to History and Philosophy of Science

PHIL 362.description: The development of economic thought from Aristotle to Adam Smith, focusing primarily on the conceptual foundations of economics, particularly the problems of value, distribution, and economic growth.
PHIL 362.longname: History and Philosophy of Economics from Aristotle to Adam Smith

PHIL 363.description: The development of economic thought from David Ricardo up to the present, including such figures as Mill, Jevons, and Keynes, focusing primarily on the conceptual foundations of economics, particularly the problems of value, distribution and growth.
PHIL 363.longname: History and Philosophy of Economics from Ricardo to Keynes

PHIL 364.description: Darwin and the science of evolution in nineteenth and early twentieth century.

PHIL 369.description: Issues common to all sciences. Philosophical questions including the character of scientific laws, theories and revolutions, the nature of scientific confirmation, causality, explanation and prediction, and the use of logic and probability. Difficulties in the interpretation of atomic physics and questions about relationships between biology and psychology. No philosophical background is assumed. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 369 or PHIL 460.

PHIL 375.description: Philosophical issues in works of literature or arising from theories of literary interpretation. Topics include issues relating to relativism, the nature of morality, free will, personal identity, the nature of the emotions.

PHIL 378.description: Epistemological and ontological thought from the Vedic Period to the period of the rise of philosophical schools or systems.  Philosophy in the Mahabharata, Gita; early Buddhist and Jain views on knowledge and reality; views on language.

PHIL 385.description: Meaning, identity and alienation as explored in the works for example of Kierkegaard, Dostoyevsky, Tolstoy, Sartre, and Camus.

PHIL 388.description: Debates on issues of epistemology, language and ontology among the philosophical schools or systems of classical India Nagarjuna, Bhartrhari, Uma-svati, Sankara and others.
PHIL 388.longname: Buddhist, Brahmanical and Jain Philosophers in Interaction.

PHIL 418.description: Intensive study of a major philosopher such as Wittgenstein, Russell, or Heidegger, or school, such as pragmatism or logical empiricism.

PHIL 427.description: Logicism, formalism and constructivism, implications of metatheorems such as those of Gï¿½del and Church, mathematical truth, mathematics and mental construction, mathematics and the physical world.
PHIL 427.prereq note: (Philosophy or mathematics courses totaling 9 credits at the 200-level or above.)
PHIL 427.prereq original: (Philosophy or mathematics courses totaling 9 credits at the 200-level or above.)

PHIL 431.description: Central concepts and problems in political life and thought including obligation, citizenship, representation, justice; equality; civil rights and liberty; disobedience.
PHIL 431.longname: Topics in Social and Political Philosophy
PHIL 431.prereq note: (9 credits of PHIL/POLI at the 200-level or above.)
PHIL 431.prereq original: (9 credits of PHIL/POLI at the 200-level or above.)

PHIL 432.description: Classic or contemporary works in ethical theory.
PHIL 432.prereq note: (9 credits of PHIL at the 200-level or above; PHIL 230 is recommended.)
PHIL 432.prereq original: (9 credits of PHIL at the 200-level or above; PHIL 230 is recommended.)

PHIL 440.description: Analysis of the concept of knowledge; problems of justifying ordinary and basic empirical beliefs.

PHIL 441.description: The contribution of the senses to knowledge of the external world; the nature of perception and its contribution to empirical knowledge.
PHIL 441.prereq note: (or COGS 200 if accompanied by 3 credits in PHIL at the 200-level or above.)
PHIL 441.prereq original: PHIL240  (or COGS 200 if accompanied by 3 credits in PHIL at the 200-level or above.)

PHIL 448.description: A study of European philosophers from amongst Husserl, Heidegger, Habermas, Foucault, Derrida, Lacan, Levinas, and others. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 448 or PHIL 449.

PHIL 450.description: Topics including ontology, universals and particulars, substance, determinism and indeterminism, identity over time, and theories of truth.
PHIL 450.prereq note: (9 credits in PHIL at the 200-level or above. PHIL 340 is recommended.)
PHIL 450.prereq original: (9 credits in PHIL at the 200-level or above. PHIL 340 is recommended.)

PHIL 451.description: The nature of the mental and physical; the relation between minds and bodies; the character of psychological explanation.
PHIL 451.prereq note: (or COGS 200 if accompanied by 3 credits of PHIL at the 200-level or above.)
PHIL 451.prereq original: PHIL240  (or COGS 200 if accompanied by 3 credits of PHIL at the 200-level or above.)

PHIL 455.description: Philosophical topics in the cognitive sciences, such as empiricism vs. nativism, consciousness, mental representation, cognitive architecture, language & thought, and situated cognition.
PHIL 455.longname: Topics in the Philosophy of Cognitive Science
PHIL 455.prereq note: (or COGS 200 if accompanied by 3 credits in PHIL at the 200-level or above.  Recommended: PHIL 441 or PHIL 451.)
PHIL 455.prereq original: PHIL 240. (or COGS 200 if accompanied by 3 credits in PHIL at the 200-level or above.  Recommended: PHIL 441 or PHIL 451.)

PHIL 461.description: Topics in the philosophy of science of special concern to the social sciences: the problem of objectivity, the use of models and evidence, causation and causal reasoning, formal methods, the status of social kinds and norms, scientific explanation, laws.
PHIL 461.prereq note: (9 credits at the 200-level or above from philosophy, anthropology, geography, economics, history, political science, psychology or sociology.)
PHIL 461.prereq original: (9 credits at the 200-level or above from philosophy, anthropology, geography, economics, history, political science, psychology or sociology.)

PHIL 469.description: Topics such as probability and induction; foundations of measurement; theory construction.

PHIL 470.description: Ways in which the 'self' has been portrayed in eastern and western religious traditions. Thinkers to be considered include Aristotle, Mencius, Freud, Xunzi (Hsï¿½n-tzu), Nietzche, and Zhuangzi (Chuang-tzu).

PHIL 491.description: Selected problems in philosophy, with attention to methods of research. Check with the department for specific topics. Primarily for fourth-year Philosophy Major students, but also open to Philosophy Honours.

PHRM 100.description: Scientific concepts and pharmacy practice principles. Role of the pharmacist, patient assessment skills, professional identity, communication skills, and an understanding of legal and ethical responsibilities.

PHRM 111.description: Modules and integration activities focusing on: an introduction to infectious diseases; musculoskeletal disorders; dermatology; eyes, ears, nose, and throat disorders; and hematology.

PHRM 131.description: Principles of clinical study design, focusing on biostatistical foundations, randomized controlled trials, and systematic review of randomized controlled trials.

PHRM 141.description: Current and future roles for pharmacists and controversies in pharmacy practice.

PHRM 161.description: Knowledge and skills related to the role and applications of technology in health care.

PHRM 170.description: Service learning activities with external community partner sites and members. Pass/Fail.

PHRM 171.description: Prescription processing, drug distribution systems, and select patient care activities in real world outpatient environments. Pass/Fail.
PHRM 171.longname: Introductory Pharmacy Practice Experience - Outpatient I

PHRM 211.description: Modules and integration activities focusing on respirology and cardiovascular disorders.

PHRM 212.description: Modules and integration activities focusing on nephrology, endocrinology, and neurology.

PHRM 221.description: Foundations of nutrition, nutrition for healthy individuals through the lifespan, and selected clinical applications of nutrition in pharmacy practice.

PHRM 231.description: Principles of clinical study design, focusing on epidemiologic studies (cohort, case-control), pharmacoeconomic analyses, non-inferiority designs, clinical prediction rules, and guidelines.

PHRM 241.description: Current and future roles for pharmacists and controversies in pharmacy practice, focusing on the roles and training opportunities for pharmacists in specialty areas of outpatient and inpatient practice.

PHRM 251.description: Preparation for experiential learning in the hospital setting. Focuses on enhancing familiarity with the care environment and developing skills suited for students to apply to patient care during institutional experiential rotations.

PHRM 270.description: Service learning activities with external community partner sites and members. Pass/Fail.

PHRM 311.description: Modules and integration activities focusing on psychiatry; gastroenterology disorders; and oncology and palliative care.

PHRM 312.description: Modules and integration activities focusing on reproductive health, sexual health, and genitourinary disorders; special infectious diseases; and toxicology.

PHRM 341.description: Current and potential roles for pharmacists, and contemporary issues in pharmacy practice. Focus on the role of pharmacists as patient educators, researchers and collaborators in interprofessional teams.

PHRM 351.description: Application of management and leadership principles and skills to pharmacy operations.

PHRM 361.description: Training for authorization to administer injections.

PHRM 441.description: Pharmacists in practice, emerging pharmacy practice issues and pharmacists as preceptors. Pass/Fail.
PHRM 441.longname: Seminar: Advanced Topics in Pharmacy Practice

PHRM 450.description: Seminar course about current and potential roles for pharmacists. Students will also deliver an individual and a group seminar. Pass/Fail.

PHRM 451.description: Principles of clinical study design, focusing on randomized controlled trials, systematic reviews, epidemiologic studies (cohort, case-control), pharmacoeconomic analyses, clinical prediction rules, and guidelines. Pass/Fail.

PHRM 452.description: Principles and practices of patient assessment, applied to the monitoring of drug efficacy and toxicity. Pass/Fail.

PHRM 453.description: Pharmacokinetic monitoring of drug therapy in common clinical situations with foundations for application to other drugs.  Pharmacogenomics and personalized medicine principles and applications to practice. Pass/Fail.

PHRM 454.description: Values, concepts, issues and responsibilities of individuals exercising leadership and management roles in pharmacy practice and health care settings. Pass/Fail.

PHRM 471.description: Application of integrated problem-solving skills to resolve increasingly complex drug-therapy problems in outpatient settings. Patient care will be provided for a wide range of therapeutic areas. Pass/Fail.

PHRM 472.description: Application of integrated problem-solving skills to resolve increasingly complex drug-therapy problems in inpatient settings. Patient care will be provided for a wide range of therapeutic areas. Pass/Fail.

PHRM 473.description: Diverse options available in such domains as patient care (various settings), research, health policy, education, and others. The available placement options will vary from year to year depending on site/preceptor availability. Pass/Fail.

PHRM 481.description: Builds on the foundation of patient care and management learning with knowledge about healthcare system improvement. Focuses on principles of quality measurement and quality improvement in health. Pass/Fail.

PHYS 100.description: Kinematics, force, energy, momentum, use of graphs and vectors in physics; thermal energy, heat transfer, Earth's energy balance; electricity. Students with credit for Physics 12 may not obtain credit for this course unless they took AP, IB, or A-level Physics and were offered advanced credit for PHYS 100.
PHYS 100.prereq note: (Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12 is required; Physics 11 is required for first-year students, strongly recommended for others.)
PHYS 100.prereq original: Not open to students with credit for PHYS 12. (Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12 is required; Physics 11 is required for first-year students, strongly recommended for others.)

PHYS 101.coreq original: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.
PHYS 101.description: Fluids, harmonic oscillator, travelling waves, standing waves, sound, and interference of light waves, including diffraction.  Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414

PHYS 107.description: Classical mechanics including conservation laws, angular momentum of rigid bodies and simple harmonic motion, wave phenomena, with an introduction to special relativity, quantum mechanics, nuclear physics, statistical mechanics and solid state physics. Please consult the Faculty of Science credit exclusion lists: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414
PHYS 107.prereq note: (MATH 12 = Principles of Mathematics 12; PREC 12 = Pre-calculus 12; CALC 12 = Calculus 12, PHYS 12 = Physics 12.)
PHYS 107.prereq original: Either (a) a score of 85% or higher in PHYS 12 and a score of 85% or higher in MATH 12;  or (b) a score of 85% or higher in PHYS 100 or (c) a score of 85% or higher in PHYS 12 and a score of 85% or higher in PREC 12;  or (d) a score of 85% or higher in PHYS 12 and a score of 85% or higher in CALC 12. (MATH 12 = Principles of Mathematics 12; PREC 12 = Pre-calculus 12; CALC 12 = Calculus 12, PHYS 12 = Physics 12.)

PHYS 108.description: Electricity and magnetism, electrical circuits, induction, electromagnetic waves, Maxwell's equations and applications. Please consult the Faculty of Science credit exclusion lists: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414
PHYS 108.prereq original: Either (a) PHYS 107 or (b) a score of 85% or higher in PHYS 101 or (c) a score of 85% or higher in PHYS 117.

PHYS 109.description: A laboratory course accompanying PHYS 108 with emphasis on data collection and analysis and experimental techniques.

PHYS 117.coreq original: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.
PHYS 117.description: Kinematics including curvilinear motion. Forces and Newton's laws of motion. Work-energy theorem, conservation of energy. Conservation of momentum, collisions. Torque, rotational dynamics, angular momentum. Oscillations and waves. Please consult the Faculty of Science credit exclusion list: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.

PHYS 118.coreq original: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121.
PHYS 118.description: Optics, electricity and magnetism, electric circuits, radioactivity, including biological applications. Please consult the Faculty of Science credit exclusion list: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
PHYS 118.prereq original: One of PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 157 and one of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.

PHYS 119.coreq original: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.
PHYS 119.description: Introductory laboratory course, with emphasis on data collection, data analysis techniques, and scientific reasoning. Please consult the Faculty of Science credit exclusion list: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
PHYS 119.prereq original: One of PHYS 12, PHYS 100, PHYS 101, PHYS 117.

PHYS 157.coreq original: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.
PHYS 157.description: Heat, thermodynamics, oscillations, waves, and sound. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.

PHYS 158.coreq original: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121.
PHYS 158.description: Electricity and magnetism, DC and AC circuits, optics. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.

PHYS 159.description: A laboratory course with emphasis on experimental design, measurement and analysis techniques. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414

PHYS 170.coreq original: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121.
PHYS 170.description: Statics of particles, equilibrium or rigid bodies, rigid body statics and internal forces, trusses; kinematics: rectilinear motion; dynamics:  Newton's second law, friction, impulse, momentum, work and energy.  Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
PHYS 170.prereq original: One of PHYS 12, PHYS 100 and one of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.

PHYS 200.description: Special relativity: Lorentz transformation, dynamics and conservation laws. Quantum physics: the experimental evidence for quantization; a qualitative discussion of the concepts of quantum mechanics and their application to simple systems of atoms and nuclei.
PHYS 200.prereq original: Either (a) one of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 158, PHYS 153 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121;  or (b) SCIE 001.

PHYS 203.coreq original: One of MATH 217, MATH 200, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263.
PHYS 203.description: Fundamentals of thermodynamics and statistical physics; entropy, laws of thermodynamics, heat engines, free energy, phase transitions, Boltzmann statistics, quantum statistics.
PHYS 203.prereq original: One of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 158, PHYS 153, SCIE 001.

PHYS 210.description: Introduction to UNIX/Linux; software tools for processing, fitting and displaying data; numerical methods and application in the physical sciences.
PHYS 210.prereq original: One of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 158, PHYS 153, SCIE 001.

PHYS 216.coreq original: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263.
PHYS 216.description: Review of kinematics, Newton's laws, angular momentum and fixed axis rotation. Rigid body motion, central forces, non-inertial frames of reference. Introduction to Lagrangian and Hamiltonian mechanics.
PHYS 216.prereq original: One of PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 170, SCIE 001 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223.

PHYS 219.coreq original: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253.
PHYS 219.description: Analog electronics and amplifiers, digital electronics, analog-to-digital converters and an introduction to use of computers in data analysis and simulations.
PHYS 219.prereq original: Either (a) one of PHYS 108, PHYS 118 and one of PHYS 109, PHYS 119;  or (b) PHYS 102 or (c) all of PHYS 158, PHYS 159 or (d) SCIE 001.

PHYS 229.description: Thermodynamics experiments, modern physics experiments and use of computers in data analysis.

PHYS 250.description: Wave-particle duality of matter, special relativity, processes in atomic, nuclear and solid state, and introduction to quantum mechanical devices and techniques.
PHYS 250.prereq original: One of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 158, PHYS 153, SCIE 001.

PHYS 298.description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the winter term of the second year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Physics.

PHYS 299.description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the summer following the second year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Physics.

PHYS 301.description: Maxwell's equations and their applications, electrical fields and potentials of static charge distributions, current, fields of moving charges, magnetic fields, electromagnetic induction.
PHYS 301.prereq original: One of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 153, PHYS 158, SCIE 001 and one of MATH 217, MATH 227, MATH 317 and one of MATH 215, MATH 255.

PHYS 304.description: Principles and applications of quantum mechanics, wave mechanics, the Schroedinger equation, expectation values, Hermitian operators, commuting observables,  one-dimensional systems, harmonic oscillators, angular momentum, three dimensional systems. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.

PHYS 305.description: Physical principles involved in biological systems at the microscopic and molecular scales. Diffusion, low Reynolds number dynamics, the physicist's view of biomolecular structure, models of molecular motors and membranes.
PHYS 305.prereq original: One of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 153, PHYS 158, SCIE 001 and either (a) PHYS 203 or (b) one of ENPH 257, CHEM 201, CHEM 205 and one of MATH 302, MATH 318, STAT 241, STAT 251, STAT 302.

PHYS 306.description: Variational calculus, Lagrangian dynamics, rigid body motion including free and forced precession, Hamiltonian mechanics, Poisson brackets, canonical coordinates, Hamilton-Jacobi theory, action angle variables. Introduction to dynamical chaos: determinism, Lyapunov exponents.
PHYS 306.prereq original: One of PHYS 216, ENPH 270 and one of MATH 215, MATH 255, MATH 256, MATH 265.

PHYS 309.description: Selected experiments in electromagnetism and electronics; computer data acquisition; advanced data analysis and simulation.

PHYS 312.description: The application of ordinary and partial differential equations to physical problems; boundary and initial value problems associated with heat, wave and Laplace equations. Fourier analysis; expansions in Bessel and Legendre functions. Credit will be granted for only one of PHYS 312 and MATH 316.

PHYS 314.description: Kinetic theory: Diffusion, viscosity and sound waves. Introduction to hydrodynamics: Laminar flow, capillary and gravity waves, convection and turbulence. Dimensional analysis.

PHYS 315.description: Crystal structure, elasticity and phonons, elementary electronic transport, defects, alloys, liquid crystals and polymers.
PHYS 315.prereq original: One of PHYS 203, ENPH 257, CHEM 201, CHEM 205, CHEM 304 and one of PHYS 200, PHYS 250, CHEM 312.

PHYS 318.description: Experimental techniques of acoustics: data acquisition hardware and software, microphones, loudspeakers, noise, vibration and modal analysis.

PHYS 319.description: A project-oriented lab introducing the design and construction of microprocessor-controlled devices.

PHYS 330.description: Quantum physics, nuclear energy and particle physics at a level suitable for third- and fourth-year Science students not proceeding to a physics degree. Not for credit towards a B.Sc. in Astronomy, Biophysics or Physics.
PHYS 330.prereq original: Either (a) one of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 180, MATH 184 and one of PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 153, PHYS 157;  or (b) SCIE 001.

PHYS 333.description: The fundamental physics behind global issues of energy use and climate change.
PHYS 333.prereq original: Either (a) one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121 and one of PHYS 101, PHYS 102, PHYS 107, PHYS 108, PHYS 117, PHYS 118, PHYS 153, PHYS 157, PHYS 158;  or (b) SCIE 001.

PHYS 340.description: Ancient Greek ideas of substance and forms and modern concepts of forces and fields. The twentieth-century quantum revolution. The modern universe, from quarks and atoms to the big bang. Quantum paradoxes. Not for credit in the faculties of Science and Applied Science. No mathematics beyond Grade 10 required.

PHYS 341.description: An introduction to the physical principles important to the production, transmission and perception of musical sounds. The treatment will be non-mathematical; with emphasis on demonstrations. Topics may include the description of sound waves, resonances, scales, physics of hearing, examination of specific musical instruments, etc. Not for credit in the Faculties of Science and Applied Science.

PHYS 343.description: A guided sequence of hands-on science modules intended primarily for prospective elementary schoolteachers, to help them to work constructively in a science teaching role. Not for credit in the Faculties of Science and Applied Science.

PHYS 348.description: Current research topics in physics and astronomy are investigated and explored. Technical communication and research skills are studied and developed via oral presentations and written scientific reports on these current research topics.
PHYS 348.prereq note: (Third-year standing in a physics honours program or fourth-year standing in a physics or astronomy major program.)
PHYS 348.prereq original: (Third-year standing in a physics honours program or fourth-year standing in a physics or astronomy major program.)

PHYS 349.description: A research project, undertaken under the direction of a faculty member, culminating in a written report. This course requires  approval of the course instructor  and  program  advisor in the Department of Physics and Astronomy.

PHYS 350.description: Review of principles. Particle mechanics: Euler's equations, tops and gyroscopes, motion of the Earth, Lagrangian and Hamiltonian methods. Variational principles in optics and mechanics, Liouville's theorem and statistical mechanics. The relationship between classical and quantum mechanics.

PHYS 399.description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the summer following the third year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Physics.

PHYS 400.description: Standard model, classification of elementary particles and forces of nature, symmetries, conservation laws, quark model, quantum electrodynamics, quantum chromodynamics, and the theory of weak interactions.

PHYS 401.description: Applications of Maxwell's theory. Wave propagation in dielectrics, conductors and plasmas, wave guides, radiation, antennae, and special relativity.

PHYS 402.description: Spin and angular momentum addition, perturbation methods, and applications in the fields of Atomic, Molecular, Nuclear, and Solid State Physics.

PHYS 403.description: Principles and applications of  statistical mechanics. Ideal gases, degenerate Fermi gases, Bose-Einstein condensation, black body radiation, fluctuations and phase transitions. Credit will be granted for only one of PHYS 403 or PHYS 455. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
PHYS 403.prereq note: (One of MATH 302, MATH 318, STAT 241, STAT 251, STAT 302 is recommended.)
PHYS 403.prereq original: One of PHYS 203, ENPH 257, PHYS 257, CHEM 201, CHEM 304 and one of PHYS 304, PHYS 450, CHEM 312. (One of MATH 302, MATH 318, STAT 241, STAT 251, STAT 302 is recommended.)

PHYS 404.description: Radiotherapy, X-ray imaging, nuclear medicine, magnetic resonance imaging and biomedical optics.
PHYS 404.prereq note: (Third yearstanding in Science or Applied Science is required. MATH 200 (or MATH 217 or MATH 226 or MATH 267) is recommended.)
PHYS 404.prereq original: (Third yearstanding in Science or Applied Science is required. MATH 200 (or MATH 217 or MATH 226 or MATH 267) is recommended.)

PHYS 405.description: Physical and chemical interactions of ionizing radiations and their biological effects at the cellular, tissue and whole-animal levels. Credit will be granted for only one of PHYS 405 or PHYS 536. See the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
PHYS 405.prereq note: (and third year standing in Science or Applied Science.)
PHYS 405.prereq original: One of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 153, PHYS 158, SCIE 001. (and third year standing in Science or Applied Science.)

PHYS 407.description: Physical consequences of Einstein's equations, including the principle of equivalence, curved space-time, geodesics, the Schwarzschild solution, deflection of light, black holes, and gravitational radiation.
PHYS 407.prereq note: (PHYS 301 and one of PHYS 206, PHYS 306 are recommended.)
PHYS 407.prereq original: One of MATH 217, MATH 227, MATH 317 and one of MATH 215, MATH 255. (PHYS 301 and one of PHYS 206, PHYS 306 are recommended.)

PHYS 408.description: Principles and applications of optical physics. Interference, diffraction, coherence, polarization, Fresnel relations, optical coatings, waves in dielectric media, Gaussian beams, waveguides, optical cavities, lasers, fibre optics, and Fourier optics.
PHYS 408.prereq original: One of PHYS 301, PHYS 354 and one of MATH 215, MATH 255.

PHYS 409.description: A laboratory course with a wide choice of experiments for fourth year Honours and Major students. Topics include solid state, nuclear, classical, quantum, electromagnetic and low temperature physics. For six credits, two weekly laboratory periods and completion of a project in second term are required.

PHYS 410.description: Scientific programming applied to problems in physics. Fundamentals of numerical analysis for continuum problems. Solution of linear and non-linear algebraic systems, ordinary differential equations and stochastic problems.
PHYS 410.prereq original: One of PHYS 312, MATH 257, MATH 316 and one of PHYS 210, EOSC 211, CPSC 110, CPSC 111, APSC 160.

PHYS 420.description: The students will prepare, under the supervision of a faculty member, a demonstration or series of demonstrations intended to illustrate physical principles to diverse audiences. Intended for third- or fourth-year Physics Majors and Math/Science Education students.

PHYS 437.description: Molecular structure and architecture of biological cells, interactions of molecules in aqueous solution and at interfaces, physical properties of polymers and surfactants, mechanisms of cell membranes and cytoplasmic structures, thermodynamics of molecular machines and mechanical enzymes. Credit can not be given for both PHYS 437 and 537.
PHYS 437.longname: Physics of Biocellular Structure and Machinery

PHYS 438.description: Animal systems viewed from a physicist's perspective. Topics include sensory systems, energy budgets, locomotion, internal flows, physical advantages of grouping.
PHYS 438.prereq original: One of PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 153, PHYS 157, SCIE 001. (BIOL 325 is recommended.)

PHYS 447.description: Directed studies available to students in Honours Physics with approval from the Head of the Department.

PHYS 449.description: A research project, undertaken under the direction of a faculty member, culminating in a thesis.

PHYS 473.description: Radioactive decay and radiations, nuclear properties, interactions of neutrons, physical principles of power reactors, nuclear fusion, radiation monitoring, and safety.

PHYS 474.description: Symmetry of crystal structures, reciprocal lattice, band theory, conduction in metals and semiconductors, phonons and superconductivity.

PHYS 490.description: Self-directed, collaborative studies, in a group-learning environment, initiated and coordinated by senior undergraduate students with the supervision of a faculty advisor. Course structure, enrolment, and delivery methods will comply with the "Handbook for Student Directed Seminars".  Cannot be used as a specialization requirement in any PHYS and/or ASTR specialization.

PHYS 498.description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the fall term of the fourth year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Physics.

PHYS 499.description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the summer following the fourth year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Physics.

PLAN 211.description: Contemporary city development trends, policies, and practices across the globe as explored against the backdrop of culture and technology. Includes hands-on learning.
PLAN 211.prereq note: (Second-year standing or above in any program.)
PLAN 211.prereq original: (Second-year standing or above in any program.)

PLAN 221.description: An exploratory journey through the vast world of visualizing the city and ways of representing the built environment, including how to both interpret and use visualizations to read the city.
PLAN 221.prereq note: (Second-year standing or above in any program.)
PLAN 221.prereq original: (Second-year standing or above in any program.)

PLAN 321.description: Place-based exploration of the multiple, complex and contested ways urban Indigeneity is constituted in Canada today, with opportunities for field trips and hands-on learning.
PLAN 321.prereq note: (Third-year standing or above in any program. Second year students may be admitted with permission of instructor.)
PLAN 321.prereq original: (Third-year standing or above in any program. Second year students may be admitted with permission of instructor.)

PLAN 331.description: Considers the city as a terrain for the manifestation and mediation of social justice. Explores how the allocation of land, goods, and services in cities (re)produces social stratification, and how institutions and civil society negotiate just and unjust outcomes.
PLAN 331.longname: The Just City in a Divided World
PLAN 331.prereq note: (Third-year standing or above in any program. Second year students may be admitted with permission of instructor.)
PLAN 331.prereq original: (Third-year standing or above in any program. Second year students may be admitted with permission of instructor.)

PLAN 341.description: Rapid transformation of cities by information technology and socio-economic innovation; growth in citizen-generated data and the internet of things; emerging theory, methods, and frameworks for understanding "Smart Cities".
PLAN 341.longname: Smart Cities: Concepts, Methods and Design
PLAN 341.prereq note: (Third-year standing or above in any program. Second year students may be admitted with permission of instructor.)
PLAN 341.prereq original: (Third-year standing or above in any program. Second year students may be admitted with permission of instructor.)

PLAN 425.description: Evolution, practice and future of urban planning and development, with emphasis on institutional arrangements, housing, transportation, urban design and development control. For third- and fourth-year undergraduate students interested in urban planning.

POLI 100.description: Political issues and case studies, drawn from Canadian and international contexts, will be used to introduce students to central debates and concepts of politics and political analysis.

POLI 101.description: An examination of the institutions and processes of Canadian government.

POLI 110.description: The logic, challenges, and major strategies of empirical political research. Core research tasks including: asking answerable questions, defining concepts, formulating hypotheses, gathering evidence, measuring variables, constructing comparisons, drawing causal inferences, and reporting findings.
POLI 110.longname: Investigating Politics: An Introduction to Scientific Political Analysis

POLI 220.description: A comparative analysis of foreign governments. Specific countries to be covered will vary according to section; consult the brochure issued by the Department.

POLI 240.description: A critical introduction to some major ideologies and traditions of Western political thought that examines their philosophical origins as well as their implications for political life.

POLI 260.description: Applies conceptual tools to topics such as war, conflict management, the global economy, poverty, and civil society.

POLI 303.description: Theory and practice of federalism; cultural duality, social stresses, and problems of flexibility. The constitution and role of the courts.

POLI 304.description: An examination of the party system, and other institutions and processes of the British Columbia political system.

POLI 308.description: An examination of one or more major issues in Canadian politics (e.g., the Charter, electoral reform). Topics will vary from year to year.

POLI 309.description: Key issues in the theory and practice of human rights in Canada. Topics will vary from year to year.

POLI 316.description: The political dynamics of Indigenous peoplesï¿½ politics on the global level; the legal and practical realities of colonization as a global Indigenous experience; current global Indigenous political issues and avenues of Indigenous resistance.

POLI 320.description: The distinctive political system of the U.S. Covers all major institutions and processes, focusing on contemporary issues. Comparisons with the Canadian system. Sources of political failure and possible reform.
POLI 320.longname: Government and Politics of the United States of America

POLI 321.description: The course will explore various aspects of Chinese politics and the dynamics of Chinaï¿½s development since 1949.  Topics include: the Cultural Revolution, political reform and protest, and economic reform policies and their consequences.

POLI 322.description: A general introduction to modern Japanese politics from various theoretical and comparative perspectives.

POLI 324.description: The political systems of contemporary Southeast Asia.

POLI 327.description: Post-1945 integration of Europe, comparison of national politics and attitudes to integration, and the history and institutions of the European Union.

POLI 328.description: Topics will vary from year to year. Consult the departmental website.

POLI 332.description: A comparative examination of democracy and authoritarianism in Latin America: populism, corporatism, bureaucratic authoritarianism, transitions from authoritarianism, and contemporary debates on the quality and diversity of democratic institutions.
POLI 332.longname: Politics and Government of Latin America

POLI 333.description: An examination of a major issue in comparative politics (e.g., the media, gender, nationalism, ethnic conflict). Topics will vary from year to year.

POLI 334.description: Literatures and theories on regime democratization around the world; the roles of political, economic, social, and international factors in encouraging or impeding democratization.

POLI 341.description: Topics may include freedom, colonialism, capitalism, Critical Theory and ideology, power and knowledge, social justice, rationalism, gender and identity politics, and the "political."

POLI 343.description: Classical origins of contemporary theories of the state, market, and civil society, focused on the relationship between social order, politics, and democracy. Readings from Smith, Toqueville, Weber, and contemporary sources.

POLI 344.description: An examination of some of the major concepts in political philosophy such as justice, equality, rights, obligation, liberty in the context of both classical and contemporary political thought.

POLI 345.description: The role of gender in Western political theory and the implications for the practice of politics.
POLI 345.longname: Gender and Politics: Political Thought and Practice

POLI 347.description: An examination of law and political theory that considers topics such as sovereignty, constitutionalism, civil disobedience, rights and the political role of judges.

POLI 348.description: Application of frameworks to policy questions that factor in debates about citizenship and social inclusion, and an examination of contemporary normative frameworks that fall along, and transcend, the left-right political spectrum.

POLI 350.description: An introduction to public policy: rationales for government intervention, the influence of interest groups and political institutions on policy outcomes, and the various stages in the policy process.

POLI 351.description: Domestic and international determinants of environmental policy; alternative approaches to environmental protection. The sustainable development paradigm; public opinion and interest group pressures; risk assessment; mandatory, voluntary and market-based policy instruments.

POLI 352.description: Policy making across industrialized democracies, with a focus on North America and Europe.

POLI 360.description: The contemporary international security context: reorientation of the study of security, patterns of inter- and intrastate conflict and communal violence, dilemmas of international response and conflict management.

POLI 361.description: A study of the nature of international violence from guerrilla to nuclear war; a survey of theories of the causes of interstate war; recent research findings on the causes of war and conditions for peace; a comparative analysis of strategies for controlling violence through disarmament and the promotion of alternative means of conflict resolution.

POLI 363.description: An analysis of Canadian foreign policy on important international issues since the 1960s and of the policy-making process. Issues may include defence commitments, economic relations, activities of international organizations, and relations with the US, Europe, USSR, Asia and the Third World.

POLI 364.description: Analysis of the activities and influence of modern international organizations in international security, economic, and social issue areas. The course will focus on organizations associated with the United Nations, but other world and regional bodies will be analysed as well.

POLI 365.description: Analysis of the foreign policies of one or more of the states of East, Southeast, and South Asia; their relations with other states in the region as well as with major outside powers.

POLI 366.description: An analysis of governmental policies and international political bargaining in regard to such issues as international investment, trade, and monetary relations. Pre-requisite: ECON 100 or 309 are recommended.

POLI 367.description: The evolution of the international system and empirical and normative theories of international relations such as realism, liberalism, and Marxism.
POLI 367.longname: International Relations Theory and the International System

POLI 369.description: An examination of issues such as interstate conflicts, terrorism, environmental change, international crime. Topics will vary from year to year.

POLI 370.description: Problems of managing conflict in the international system (e.g., intervention, mediation, sanctions). Topics will vary from year to year.

POLI 372.description: Multinational corporations and the state in the contemporary international system, including the impact of multinationals and foreign direct investment on governments, societies, and industry.
POLI 372.prereq note: (Third year standing. Previous completion of an introductory course in international relations (e.g. POLI 260 or its equivalent) is very strongly recommended.)
POLI 372.prereq original: (Third year standing. Previous completion of an introductory course in international relations (e.g. POLI 260 or its equivalent) is very strongly recommended.)

POLI 373.description: When is it right to wage war?  Who should pay for global warming?  Should the wealthy provide foreign aid- how much?  Analysis of traditions of moral thought to reach reasoned judgments about such dilemmas in global politics.

POLI 374.description: The development of peacekeeping within and outside the United Nations system and as an instrument of conflict management.

POLI 375.description: Ecological consequences of the global political economy.

POLI 377.description: Evolution and contemporary significance of nuclear weapons and arms control policy and technology from the perspective of the physical and life sciences and the social sciences and humanities.
POLI 377.prereq note: (Third-year standing in B.A. or B.Sc. progrm, or second-year standing in B.A.Sc. program)
POLI 377.prereq original: (Third-year standing in B.A. or B.Sc. progrm, or second-year standing in B.A.Sc. program)

POLI 378.description: Exploration of contemporary terrorism as a contested area of understanding and as a social construct.  Includes origins and motives, evolution of terrorist groups, strategies and tactics, and anti-terrorism and counter-terrorism responses.

POLI 379.description: Impact and implications of the rise of China in historical and contemporary perspective.
POLI 379.prereq note: (Third year standing. Previous coursework on international relations or POLI 321 are recommended.)
POLI 379.prereq original: (Third year standing. Previous coursework on international relations or POLI 321 are recommended.)

POLI 380.description: An introduction to quantitative methods as utilized in the study of Political Science. Not available for credit in the Faculty of Commerce and Business Administration.

POLI 390.description: An examination of the dimensions of Political Science and the major debates within the discipline.

POLI 402.description: Seminar on the origins and development of the Canadian Constitution: the political aspects of federalism and the legal consequences of the Charter of Rights.
POLI 402.longname: Law and Politics of the Canadian Constitution
POLI 402.prereq original: POLI 101 and one of POLI 301, POLI 302, POLI 303, POLI 304, POLI 305, POLI 306, POLI 307, POLI 308.

POLI 405.description: This seminar examines in depth some of the important issues in Canadian politics.
POLI 405.prereq original: POLI 101 and one of POLI 301, POLI 302, POLI 303, POLI 304, POLI 305, POLI 306, POLI 307, POLI 308.

POLI 420.description: Seminar in comparative analysis of politics in democratic systems. For specific content in a given year, consult the departmental website.
POLI 420.prereq original: Two of POLI 220, POLI 320, POLI 321, POLI 322, POLI 323, POLI 324, POLI 325, POLI 326, POLI 327, POLI 328, POLI 329, POLI 330, POLI 331, POLI 332, POLI 333, POLI 350, POLI 351.

POLI 421.description: A seminar devoted to comparative analysis of politics in non-western states. For specific content in a given year, consult the departmental website.
POLI 421.longname: Advanced Topics in Comparative Politics: Non-Western
POLI 421.prereq original: Two of POLI 220, POLI 320, POLI 321, POLI 322, POLI 323, POLI 324, POLI 325, POLI 326, POLI 327, POLI 328, POLI 329, POLI 330, POLI 331, POLI 332, POLI 333, POLI 350, POLI 351.

POLI 422.description: A seminar devoted to intensive analysis of a contemporary political problem from a comparative perspective, e.g., ethnic politics, class politics, the politics of post-industrial society. For specific content in a given year, consult the departmental website.
POLI 422.prereq original: Two of POLI 220, POLI 320, POLI 321, POLI 322, POLI 323, POLI 324, POLI 325, POLI 326, POLI 327, POLI 328, POLI 329, POLI 330, POLI 331, POLI 332, POLI 333, POLI 350, POLI 351.

POLI 423.description: Seminar in comparative analysis of constitutionalism, authoritarianism, democracy, etc. For specific content in a given year, consult the departmental website.
POLI 423.prereq original: Two of POLI 220, POLI 320, POLI 321, POLI 322, POLI 323, POLI 324, POLI 325, POLI 326, POLI 327, POLI 328, POLI 329, POLI 330, POLI 331, POLI 332, POLI 333, POLI 350, POLI 351.

POLI 428.description: Major changes in the structures and processes of government in advanced democracies, including the welfare state, citizenship, ethics, accountability, and institutional reform.
POLI 428.prereq note: (Restricted to Major/Honour POLI or Combined Major with POLI.)
POLI 428.prereq original: (Restricted to Major/Honour POLI or Combined Major with POLI.)

POLI 439.description: The relationship between politics, economics, and development. The role of the state, political institutions, economic policy, and foreign aid in development strategies.

POLI 440.description: This seminar examines the political ideas of leading political philosophers of the twentieth century. Consult the departmental website.

POLI 441.description: Approaches to political criticism: Critical Theory, Foucauldian genealogy, critical realism, and feminism, including forms of domination, which shape people's beliefs and self-conceptions.
POLI 441.longname: Interpretation and Criticism in Political Theory

POLI 445.description: Traditions of critical social theory, broadly construed, to examine the modern politics of 'race,' racism, and racialized identities.
POLI 445.longname: Critical Theory: Policitical Theory and the Problems of Race

POLI 446.description: Seminar will examines how "identity" is theorized in contemporary political thought, beginning with the role that identity plays in the "western" canon and proceeding to examine feminist, multicultural, queer, and post-colonial theories of citizenship along with their critics.

POLI 460.description: A seminar devoted to the analysis of the foreign policies of one or more states, as well as to the study of literature pertaining to foreign policy analysis. For specific content in a given year, consult the departmental website.
POLI 460.prereq original: Two of POLI 260, POLI 360, POLI 361, POLI 362, POLI 363, POLI 364, POLI 365, POLI 366, POLI 367, POLI 368, POLI 369, POLI 370.

POLI 461.description: A seminar on a selected topic concerning the causes of war and strategies for the promotion of peace. For specific content in a given year, consult the departmental website.
POLI 461.prereq original: Two of POLI 260, POLI 360, POLI 361, POLI 362, POLI 363, POLI 364, POLI 365, POLI 366, POLI 367, POLI 368, POLI 369, POLI 370.

POLI 462.description: This seminar examines some of the major theoretical approaches to the study of international relations. For specific content in a given year, consult the departmental website.
POLI 462.prereq original: Two of POLI 260, POLI 360, POLI 361, POLI 362, POLI 363, POLI 364, POLI 365, POLI 366, POLI 367, POLI 368, POLI 369, POLI 370.

POLI 463.description: This seminar analyses issues relating to the politics of international economic relations. For specific content in a given year, consult the brochure issued by the Department.
POLI 463.prereq original: Two of POLI 260, POLI 360, POLI 361, POLI 362, POLI 363, POLI 364, POLI 365, POLI 366, POLI 367, POLI 368, POLI 369, POLI 370. (6 credits of ECON are recommended.)

POLI 464.description: Content varies from year to year. Consult the departmental website. One section (of 3 credits) is reserved for fourth-year students in the Major program in International Relations.

POLI 492.description: In consultation with faculty, students develop a research project, report on their project during seminars, give feedback on their fellow students' projects, and write a thesis.

POLS 200.description: Introduction to contemporary Polish. Oral practice, grammar, reading, writing.

POLS 426.description: The German Nazi Holocaust in Polish Literature and film.
POLS 426.longname: The German Nazi Holocaust in Polish Literature and Film (in English)

PORT 101.description: Grammar, composition, translation, oral practice. Credit will be granted for only one of PORT 101 or PORT 110.

PORT 102.description: Grammar, composition, translation, oral practice. Credit will be granted for only one of PORT 102 or PORT 110.

PORT 201.description: Grammar, composition, translation, oral practice, readings. Credit will be granted for only one of PORT 201 or PORT 210

PORT 202.description: Grammar, composition, translation, oral practice, readings. Credit may be granted for only one of PORT 202 or PORT 210.

PORT 301.description: Advanced work in composition for students who have reached the Language-Requirement level of Portuguese.

PSYC 101.description: Introduction to Methods and Statistics, Biopsychology, Learning, Perception, Memory, and Cognition. Credit will be granted for only one of PSYC 100 and PSYC 101.
PSYC 101.longname: Introduction to Biological and Cognitive Psychology

PSYC 102.description: Introduction to methods and statistics, motivation, assessment, developmental, personality, clinical, and social psychology. Credit will be granted for only one of PSYC 100 and PSYC 102.
PSYC 102.longname: Introduction to Developmental, Social, Personality, and Clinical Psychology

PSYC 205.description: Topics include addiction, culture and evolution in social behaviour, personal relationships, pro- and anti-social behaviour, judgment and decision-making, prejudice and discrimination. Consult the Psychology Department for topics offered each term. May be repeated on a different topic once for credit.

PSYC 207.description: A focus on the interpretation of contemporary research in neuroscience, cognition, perception, memory, and learning.
PSYC 207.longname: Contemporary Topics in Biological and Cognitive Psychology

PSYC 208.description: A focus on the interpretation of contemporary research in social, developmental, personality, and clinical psychology.
PSYC 208.longname: Contemporary Topics in Social, Developmental, Personality, and Clinical Psychology

PSYC 216.description: Use basic principles of quantitative psychological research methods to critique psychological claims presented in the media and to translate psychological science to everyday life.
PSYC 216.longname: Questioning Psychological Science in the Media

PSYC 217.coreq original: Either(a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102.
PSYC 217.description: Focus on various research methods used in psychology, with an emphasis on critical thinking and experimental design.  Restricted to students in the Faculty of Arts who have declared their major in one of Psychology, Cognitive Systems, or Speech Sciences (Linguistics Department).

PSYC 218.coreq original: Either(a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102.
PSYC 218.description: Use of inferential statistics in psychology and conceptual interpretation of data; experimental design (laboratory, field research methods); presentation of data analyses in reports. PSYC 218 excludes credit for a number of other statistics courses in various departments. Please consult the Science Exclusion List (www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414) before registering.
PSYC 218.prereq note: (And a major in Psychology, Cognitive Systems, or Speech Sciences.)
PSYC 218.prereq original: PSYC 217. (And a major in Psychology, Cognitive Systems, or Speech Sciences.)

PSYC 260.coreq original: Either(a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102.
PSYC 260.description: Detailed introduction to experimental and theoretical aspects of motivation, sensation, perception and learning.
PSYC 260.prereq note: (Completion of first-year Science program and permission of the department head is also required.)
PSYC 260.prereq original: (Completion of first-year Science program and permission of the department head is also required.)

PSYC 270.prereq note: (And second-year standing in a Behavioural Neuroscience specialization.)
PSYC 270.prereq original: Either (a) SCIE 001 and BIOL 140;  or (b) one of CHEM 111, CHEM 121, CHEM 123 and all of BIOL 121, BIOL 140. (And second-year standing in a Behavioural Neuroscience specialization.)

PSYC 277.description: Research methods used in behavioural neuroscience.
PSYC 277.prereq note: (And second-year standing in a Behavioural Neuroscience specialization.)
PSYC 277.prereq original: Either (a) SCIE 001 and BIOL 140;  or (b) one of CHEM 111, CHEM 121, CHEM 123 and all of BIOL 121, BIOL 140. (And second-year standing in a Behavioural Neuroscience specialization.)

PSYC 278.description: Statistical methods for use in behavioural neuroscience.
PSYC 278.longname: Analysis of Behavioural and Neuroscientific Data

PSYC 300.description: The definition, history, and scope of abnormal behaviour; emphasis on the psychological factors that control its origins, maintenance, and modification.
PSYC 300.prereq original: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217. (Strongly recommended: PSYC 101, 102, and PSYC 216 or 217.)

PSYC 301.description: Cognitive and behavioral impairments resulting from brain dysfunction. Focus on the efficacy of various intervention approaches.
PSYC 301.prereq original: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217. (Strongly recommended: PSYC 101, 102, and PSYC 216 or 217.)

PSYC 302.description: Human cognition, perception, motor, social, emotional needs, brain development and their interactions from birth until the emergence of language.
PSYC 302.prereq original: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217. (Strongly recommended: PSYC 101, 102, and PSYC 216 or 217.)

PSYC 303.description: Theory and practice of psychological measurement, statistical models for items and tests, assessment of test reliability and validity, factor analysis, scoring.

PSYC 304.description: The neurobiological bases of behaviour; brain processes involved in perception, motivation, emotion, psychopathology, learning and memory. Open to all Arts and Science majors except those in the B.Sc. Psychology program. Credit will be granted for only one of PSYC 304 or PSYC 360.
PSYC 304.prereq note: (Strongly recommended: PSYC 101 and PSYC 216 or 217 or 260.)
PSYC 304.prereq original: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217. (Strongly recommended: PSYC 101 and PSYC 216 or 217 or 260.)

PSYC 305.description: Theory and research on individual differences in motivation, emotion, and social behaviour.
PSYC 305.prereq original: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217. (Strongly recommended: PSYC 102 and PSYC 216 or 217.)

PSYC 306.description: Behavioural neuroscience; behavioural genetics; social systems; mating and parental strategies; instinct and learning; evolution of human behaviour. Credit will be given for only one of BIOL 310 or PSYC 306.
PSYC 306.prereq note: (Strongly recommended: PSYC 101 and one of PSYC 216 or 217.)
PSYC 306.prereq original: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217. (Strongly recommended: PSYC 101 and one of PSYC 216 or 217.)

PSYC 307.description: Cultural influences on human thought and behaviour; interactions of culture and self; multicultural experiences; intercultural relations; methodological issues.
PSYC 307.prereq original: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217. (Strongly recommended: PSYC 102 and PSYC 216 or 217.)

PSYC 308.description: Theory and research of individual social behaviour; social motivation; attitudes; group interaction; socialization; prejudice.
PSYC 308.prereq original: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217. (Strongly recommended: PSYC 102 and PSYC 216 or 217.)

PSYC 309.description: Contribution of cognitive processes to perception, attention, and memory; cognitive development, language, thinking, and creativity.
PSYC 309.prereq original: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217. (Strongly recommended: PSYC 101 and PSYC 216 or 217.)

PSYC 311.description: Psychological theory, research, and skills training related to sport performance, exercise motivation, and adherence. Credit will be granted for only one of PSYC 311 and HKIN 231 and 364.
PSYC 311.prereq original: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217. (Strongly recommended: PSYC 216 or 217.)

PSYC 312.description: The principal trends of psychological explanation and events in the history of psychology from the earliest times to the present. Open only to Major or Honours students or by permission of the instructor.
PSYC 312.prereq original: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217. (Strongly recommended: PSYC 101 and PSYC 216 or 217.)

PSYC 314.description: Health-related behaviours such as smoking and drug use; effects of stressful events on health; methods for coping with stress; impact of chronic illness on the family; social support systems.
PSYC 314.prereq original: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217. (Strongly recommended: PSYC 102 and PSYC 216 or 217.)

PSYC 315.description: Human development from the preschool period through adolescence.
PSYC 315.prereq original: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217. (Strongly recommended: PSYC 102 and PSYC 216 or 217.)

PSYC 319.description: Applications of theories and research in developmental psychology to contemporary social issues; topics may include daycare, child abuse, divorce and remarriage, substance abuse, sexuality.
PSYC 319.prereq original: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217. (Strongly recommended: PSYC 102 and PSYC 216 or 217.)

PSYC 320.description: Theory and research on gender development and the influence of sex and/or gender on cognition, emotion, motivation, social behaviour, and health.
PSYC 320.prereq original: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217. (Strongly recommended: PSYC 216 or 217.)

PSYC 321.description: Psychological theory and research on the interaction between organisms and the physical environment; emphasis on applications to the design and management of constructed and natural environments.
PSYC 321.prereq original: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217. (Strongly recommended: PSYC 101 and PSYC 216 or 217.)

PSYC 322.description: Issues, theories, and psychological research regarding adulthood and the aging process.
PSYC 322.prereq original: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217. (Strongly recommended: PSYC 102 and PSYC 216 or 217.)

PSYC 325.description: Examines human development in the context of the socializing role of media.
PSYC 325.prereq original: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217. (Strongly recommended: PSYC 102 and PSYC 216 or 217.)

PSYC 331.description: The application of psychological theory and research to legal issues and the criminal justice system.
PSYC 331.prereq original: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217. (Strongly recommended: PSYC 102 and PSYC 216 or 217.)

PSYC 333.description: Classical and contemporary metaphors for memory and their impact on theory development.
PSYC 333.longname: Memory: Historical, Clinical and Cognitive Perspectives
PSYC 333.prereq note: (Strongly recommended: PSYC 101 and PSYC 216 or 217. Non-PSYC students may substitute LING 420 or LING 200 and 201 for the above prerequisite.)
PSYC 333.prereq original: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217. (Strongly recommended: PSYC 101 and PSYC 216 or 217. Non-PSYC students may substitute LING 420 or LING 200 and 201 for the above prerequisite.)

PSYC 335.description: The psychology of gambling behaviour, with emphasis on relevant work from judgment and decision-making, the cognitive neuroscience of choice, and clinical perspectives on disordered gambling.
PSYC 335.prereq original: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217. (Strongly recommended: PSYC 101 and PSYC 216 or 217.)

PSYC 336.description: Psychological abilities underlying human language; language processing, lexical representation, and principles of online conversation; animal versus human communication.
PSYC 336.prereq note: (Strongly recommended: PSYC 101 and PSYC 216 or 217. Non-PSYC students may substitute ENGL 329, or LING 420, or LING 200 and 201 for the above prerequisite.)
PSYC 336.prereq original: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217. (Strongly recommended: PSYC 101 and PSYC 216 or 217. Non-PSYC students may substitute ENGL 329, or LING 420, or LING 200 and 201 for the above prerequisite.)

PSYC 340.description: Directed investigation of a problem, requiring a written report of the findings.
PSYC 340.prereq note: (At least 72% average in the preceding 30 credits and permission of a faculty member who is prepared to supervise the investigation.)
PSYC 340.prereq original: (At least 72% average in the preceding 30 credits and permission of a faculty member who is prepared to supervise the investigation.)

PSYC 348.description: Directed investigation of an experimental problem requiring a written report of the findings.
PSYC 348.prereq note: (At least 72% average in the preceding 30 credits and permission of a faculty member who is prepared to supervise the investigation.)
PSYC 348.prereq original: (At least 72% average in the preceding 30 credits and permission of a faculty member who is prepared to supervise the investigation.)

PSYC 349.description: Orientation to psychological research, with special emphasis on ongoing research within the department; effective presentation of research findings, oral and written; critical evaluation of research. Requires a research project.
PSYC 349.prereq original: Either(a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102;  and all of PSYC 217,  218.

PSYC 350.description: Human sexuality from a biopsychological, behavioural, and psychosocial perspective.
PSYC 350.prereq original: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217. (Strongly recommended: PSYC 216 or 217.)

PSYC 358.description: Theory and research on the evolution of the human mind, with emphasis on implications for cognition and behaviour in contemporary environments.
PSYC 358.prereq original: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217. (Strongly recommended: PSYC 102 and PSYC 216 or 217.)

PSYC 359.description: Prepares students for graduate studies or other advanced behavioural research; experimental design and analytic techniques; laboratory with computer applications.
PSYC 359.longname: Advanced Research Methods in Behavioural Sciences
PSYC 359.prereq original: Either(a) all of PSYC 217, PSYC 218 or (b) PSYC 366.

PSYC 360.description: The relationship between the nervous system and behaviour; the physiological basis of perception, motivation, learning, and memory. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.

PSYC 361.description: Experimental analysis of hunger, thirst, exploratory and curiosity behaviour, maternal and reproductive behaviour, fixed action patterns, and complex processes involved in social motivation with emphasis on the biological basis of motivation.
PSYC 361.prereq original: One of PSYC 260, PSYC 270, PSYC 304, PSYC 360, PSYC 370.

PSYC 363.description: Introduction to basic theories of non-associative learning, classical and operant conditioning. Experimental findings from behavioural and biological analyses with animals and humans.
PSYC 363.prereq original: One of BIOL 260, BIOL 361, BIOL 455, BIOL 458, CAPS 301, PSYC 260, PSYC 263, PSYC 270, PSYC 304.

PSYC 365.description: Brain mechanisms underlying cognitive processes such as perception, attention, consciousness, and memory.

PSYC 366.description: Detailed coverage of basic research methods; the design of experiments and statistical analysis; methods will be applied in laboratory and project work. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List:  www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.

PSYC 367.description: Anatomy and physiology of the sensory pathways and their relation to perception.
PSYC 367.prereq original: Either(a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102. (or (c) 6 credits of 200-level Psychology (but not 205 or 263).)

PSYC 368.description: Perceptual phenomena and their underlying brain mechanisms.

PSYC 370.description: Advanced methods and topics in behavioural neuroscience.
PSYC 370.prereq original: One of PSYC 260, PSYC 270 and one of PSYC 217, PSYC 277 and one of PSYC 218, PSYC 278.

PSYC 371.description: Neurodevelopment and neuroplasticity, the physiological bases of several motivated behaviours (sleep, sexual behaviour, hunger and eating, drugs and addiction), cognition, the stress response, and brain dysfunction and recovery.

PSYC 388.description: Directed investigation of an experimental problem in Behavioural Neuroscience requiring a written report of the findings.
PSYC 388.prereq note: (At least 72% average in the preceding 30 credits, permission of the supervisor, and permission of the department.)
PSYC 388.prereq original: (At least 72% average in the preceding 30 credits, permission of the supervisor, and permission of the department.)

PSYC 398.description: Approved and supervised relevant work experience in an industrial, academic, or government setting for a minimum of 13 weeks, full-time. Normally taken in Summer Session after third year. Work term report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in Psychology (B.Sc.).

PSYC 399.description: Approved and supervised relevant work experience in an industrial, academic, or government setting for a minimum of 13 weeks, full-time. Normally taken in fourth year Winter Session, Term 1. Work term report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in Psychology (B.Sc.).

PSYC 400.description: Theory, research, practice, and professional issues in clinical psychology, including a practicum placement. Credit will be granted for only one of PSYC 400 and 401.

PSYC 401.description: Theoretical and research foundations of the processes of assessment and behaviour modification in clinical psychology. Credit will be granted for only one of PSYC 400 or PSYC 401.

PSYC 402.description: Focus on the cognitive, biological, and motivational underpinnings of psychological disorders. Topics include current research methods, controversies in the research literature, and directions for future research.
PSYC 402.prereq original: Either (a) all of PSYC 217, PSYC 218 or (b) all of PSYC 300, PSYC 366.

PSYC 404.description: Cognitive, emotional, and motivational underpinnings of religious behaviour; supernatural beliefs, magical thinking, ritual, sacrifice; religion's role in morality, prosociality, health, violence, and intergroup relations.
PSYC 404.prereq original: One of PSYC 217, PSYC 366 and one of PSYC 305, PSYC 307, PSYC 308, PSYC 358.

PSYC 409.description: The structure of the mind as revealed by brain injury, neurological illness, and surgical intervention.  Topics include attention, memory, language, sense of self, topographic awareness, moral reasoning, emotion, theory of mind, and social awareness.
PSYC 409.prereq original: Either (a) all of PSYC 217, PSYC 218 or (b) PSYC 366 and one of PSYC 309, PSYC 365.

PSYC 412.description: The development of fundamental cognitive abilities from infancy through adulthood, including traditional approaches to cognitive development as well as new areas of current investigation.
PSYC 412.prereq original: one of PSYC302, PSYC315, PSYC319, PSYC322, PSYC325

PSYC 413.description: Comprehensive overview of the psychological processes in the social and personality development of infants, children, and adolescents.
PSYC 413.prereq original: one of PSYC302, PSYC315, PSYC319, PSYC322, PSYC325

PSYC 420.description: The relationships between social contexts and wellbeing with a focus on disadvantaged populations.  Students engage in a community service placement to complement academic learning.
PSYC 420.prereq original: Either (a) PSYC 300 or (b) PSYC 308 or (c) PSYC 314 or (d) PSYC 319.

PSYC 421.description: Psychological theory and research on the interaction between organisms and the physical environment; emphasis on applications to the design and management of constructed and natural environments.  Credit will be granted for only one of PSYC 421 or PSYC 321.
PSYC 421.prereq original: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217. (Strongly recommended: PSYC 101 and PSYC 216 or 217.)

PSYC 440.description: Directed investigation of an experimental problem, requiring a written report of the findings.
PSYC 440.prereq note: (At least 72% average in the preceding 30 credits and permission of a faculty member who is prepared to supervise the investigation.)
PSYC 440.prereq original: (At least 72% average in the preceding 30 credits and permission of a faculty member who is prepared to supervise the investigation.)

PSYC 448.description: Directed investigation of an experimental problem requiring a written report of the findings.
PSYC 448.prereq note: (At least a 72% average in the preceding 30 credits and permission of a faculty member who is prepared to supervise the investigation.)
PSYC 448.prereq original: (At least a 72% average in the preceding 30 credits and permission of a faculty member who is prepared to supervise the investigation.)

PSYC 449.description: Students carry out a research project and report on its development during seminars. Students also discuss research by Departmental staff, with emphasis on choice of problems, research design and data analysis.

PSYC 460.description: Detailed examination of the interaction between hormones and neural control of reproductive and non-reproductive behaviours; emphasis on gonadal and adrenal hormone effects on learning and memory in the brain.

PSYC 461.description: Experimental findings and theory documenting the plasticity of the brain and its relationship to behaviour: emphasis on gene regulation, neurogenesis and cell morphology changes in relation to learning and experience.

PSYC 462.description: Introduction to neurochemical systems and functional neuroanatomy; animal models of human cognitive processes and mental disorders; neurochemical foundations and treatments for mental disorders.
PSYC 462.prereq original: One of PSYC 304, PSYC 360. (BIOL 205 and/or PCTH 325 recommended.)

PSYC 472.description: Neurobiological pathways mediating five core aspects of motivated behaviour: (1) affective decision making; (2) motivated drive; (3) goal-directed vs. habit-based behaviour; (4) learning from negative reinforcers; and (5) disorders of motivation.

PSYC 488.description: Directed investigation of an experimental problem in Behavioural Neuroscience requiring a written report of the findings.
PSYC 488.prereq note: (At least 72% average in the preceding 30 credits, permission of the supervisor, and permission of the department.)
PSYC 488.prereq original: (At least 72% average in the preceding 30 credits, permission of the supervisor, and permission of the department.)

PSYC 498.description: Approved and supervised relevant work experience in an industrial, academic, or government setting for a minimum of 13 weeks, full-time. Normally taken in fourth year Winter Session, Term 2. Work term report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in Psychology (B.Sc.).

PSYC 499.description: Approved and supervised relevant work experience in an industrial, academic, or government setting for a minimum of 13 weeks, full time. Normally taken in Summer Session after fourth year. Work term report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in Psychology (B.Sc.).

PUNJ 100.description: Spoken and written Punjabi. Credit will be granted for only one of PUNJ 100 or PUNJ 102. Students who have taken Punjabi 11 in high school cannot take PUNJ 100 for credit.

PUNJ 101.description: Continuation of PUNJ 100. Credit will be granted for only one of PUNJ 101 or PUNJ 102. Students who have taken Punjabi 11 in high school cannot take PUNJ 101 for credit.

PUNJ 102.description: Spoken and written Punjabi. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of PUNJ 100/101 or PUNJ 102. Students who have taken Punjabi 11 in high school cannot take PUNJ 102 for credit.

PUNJ 200.description: Study of the grammar and introduction to Punjabi literature. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of PUNJ 201/202 or PUNJ 200.

PUNJ 300.description: Advanced grammar and conversation. Major genres of Punjabi literature. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of PUNJ 301/302 or PUNJ 300.

PUNJ 401.description: Emphasis is on reading and written expression. Analytical writing in English and Punjabi required.

PUNJ 402.description: Emphasis is on reading and written expression. Analytical writing in English and Punjabi required.

PUNJ 403.description: Popular and literary works in modern Punjabi, with a focus on short stories and poetry. Emphasis on reading, writing, and vocabulary development.

PUNJ 457.description: Punjabi-language theatre, with emphasis on Canadian forms. Reading, writing, and performance of plays; examination of history of Punjabi theatre.
