PUNJ 475.description: Develops students' oral expression and listening comprehension in Punjabi through Community Based Learning. Students engage in oral history collection in the Punjabi-speaking community and develop short video or sound projects. Analytical reading and writing required.

RELG 101.description: An overview of the three main western monotheistic (Abrahamic) religions, together with the concepts used in studying religion, The focus will be on the origins and representative texts along with some historical development and current experience of each religion.
RELG 101.longname: Introduction to the Western (Abrahamic) Religions: Judaism, Christianity, and Islam

RELG 201.description: An introduction to the world of Near Eastern mythology, from the Gilgamesh Epic to the Book of Genesis and beyond.

RELG 203.description: An introduction to the scriptures of Judaism, Christianity, and Islam.

RELG 207.description: The history and culture, values, and achievements of Islamic societies from 700-1500; the interconnections between power, politics, gender, and the arts in Islamic societies. This course is highly recommended as a basis for all 300- and 400-level Islamic Studies courses.

RELG 208.description: The history and culture, values, and socio-political movements of the Islamic world from 1500 to the modern day; the interconnections between power, politics, gender, and the arts in modern Islamic societies. This course is highly recommended as a basis for all 300- and 400-level Islamic Studies courses.

RELG 306.description: The impact of archaeological research on understanding the history and religion of ancient Israel.

RELG 307.description: An exploration of the Bible's "dark side," with emphasis on texts that center on sex, deceit, and murder.
RELG 307.longname: Sex, Lies, and Violence in the Hebrew Bible

RELG 308.description: The Talmud, Midrash, and other late-antique (3rd - 7th centuries) rabbinic writings, focusing on biblical interpretation and narratives.
RELG 308.longname: Talmud, Midrash and the Rabbinic Imagination

RELG 415.description: The life and literature of Paul in the Roman imperial world: letter writing, patronage and power; Roman imperial iconography; Paul and community formation.
RELG 415.longname: The Life and Thought of Paul of Tarsus

RELG 475.description: Consult the course registration information each year for offered topics.

RGLA 372.description: The topic is selected and announced annually by the RGLA Committee.
RGLA 372.longname: Topics in Religion, Literature, and the Arts

RGLA 471.description: Application of critical methods to one or more major authors.
RGLA 471.longname: Advanced Seminar in Religion and Literature

RHSC 420.description: An introduction to the structure and function of the human nervous system.

RMST 221.description: An introduction to the main themes that shaped the Western part of Europe as its different national identities emerged in the Mediterranean sphere.
RMST 221.longname: Literatures and Cultures of the Romance World I: Medieval to Early Modern

RMST 222.description: An introduction to the main themes that shaped the Western part of Europe in the age of the nation state, imperialism, colonization, and decolonization.
RMST 222.longname: Literatures and Cultures of the Romance World II: Modern to Post-Modern

RMST 420.longname: Studies in Romance Languages and Literature

RUSS 101.description: Introduction to contemporary Russian with emphasis on specialized vocabulary for science, commerce, law, etc. Oral practice, grammar, reading and writing. Note: Students who intend to use RUSS 101, 102 and 200 to satisfy the Faculty of Arts language requirement must register for both RUSS 101 and 102 in the same year.

RUSS 201.description: Intermediate oral practice, grammar, reading, composition. A special section may be provided for Science students. Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS 201 or RUSS 200.

RUSS 202.description: A continuation of RUSS 201. Intermediate oral practice, grammar, reading, composition. A special section may be provided for Science students. Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS 202 or RUSS 200.

RUSS 206.description: The writings, lives, and thought of selected authors.

RUSS 207.description: The writings, lives, and thought of major Russian authors.

RUSS 300.description: Intermediate oral practice, syntax and composition.

RUSS 306.description: A comprehensive historical and critical presentation with emphasis on the nineteenth and twentieth centuries.

RUSS 316.description: Conversation and composition using Russian film.

RUSS 323.description: Russian genre fiction and film (science fiction, fantasy and gothic).
RUSS 323.longname: Fantastic Worlds in Russian Fiction (in English)

RUSS 400.description: Advanced oral practice, reading and composition.

SANS 300.description: Basic vocabulary and most important grammatical features of classical Sanskrit. Useful to students of South Asian history, culture, languages, philosophies, and religions, and of linguistics and classics. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 300 or SANS 102 or both SANS 100, SANS 101 or both SANS 301, SANS 302.

SANS 301.description: Basic vocabulary and most important grammatical features of classical Sanskrit. Useful to students of South Asian history, culture, languages, philosophies, and religions, and of linguistics and classics. No prior proficiency in Sanskrit required. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 301 or SANS 100 or SANS 300.

SANS 302.description: Continuation of SANS 301. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 302 or SANS 101 or SANS 300.

SANS 400.description: Advanced grammar and selected readings. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 400 or SANS 200 or both SANS 201, SANS 202 or both SANS 401, SANS 402.

SANS 401.description: Advanced grammar and selected readings. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 401 or SANS 201 or SANS 400.

SCAN 335.description: History, literature, and mythology of early Scandinavian societies.

SCAN 336.description: Crime fictions and films as a mirror of Scandinavian society.

SCAN 413.description: An examination through literature of the historical, cultural, and ethnic elements that have made the Baltic area the crossroads of northeastern Europe. The emphasis is on literature from the Germanic  and Finno-Ugric languages. Authors to be studied include Strindberg, Tikkanen, Transtromer, Kaplinski, Grass, Bobrowski, Lenz.
SCAN 413.longname: The Literatures of the Baltic in English Translation

SCAN 414.description: Selected topics, such as ethnicity, migration, identity, women's issues, Danish and Northern European film.
SCAN 414.longname: Topics in Danish and Northern European Cultural Studies (in English).

SCAN 415.description: Scandinavian contributions to medieval and early modern world literature, culture and history.
SCAN 415.longname: The World of the Sagas (in English)

SCIE 001.description: An innovative first-year multidisciplinary course incorporating biology, chemistry, mathematics, and physics with a strong focus on the connections between these traditional disciplines.  See the Science One website (www.scienceone.ubc.ca)  for further information and the application process for admission to SCIE 001.
SCIE 001.prereq original: Either (a) BIOL 11 or (b) BIOL 12;  and all of CHEM 12, CALC 12, PHYS 12, ENGL 12. (and Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12.)

SCIE 113.description: Small-group experience where students study science in society, scientific process, and how to communicate scientific concepts.  Enrollment limited to students with first-year standing in the B. Sc. program in Science.

SCIE 120.coreq note: (Restricted to students with first-year standing in Science.)
SCIE 120.coreq original: One of BIOL 111, BIOL 121 and one of CHEM 111, CHEM 121. (Restricted to students with first-year standing in Science.)
SCIE 120.description: Topics in sustainability, based on concepts introduced in first-year Science courses.

SCIE 300.coreq note: (and 3rd or 4th year standing in Combined Major in Science.)
SCIE 300.coreq original: One of BIOL 300, STAT 200, STAT 241. (and 3rd or 4th year standing in Combined Major in Science.)
SCIE 300.description: Effective communication and presentation skills in science.

SCIE 420.description: Explores systems thinking in the context of sustainability and also re-examines the familiar three pillar model of sustainability - society, ecology, and economics - highlighting its uses and limitations.
SCIE 420.longname: Sustainability for Community and the World
SCIE 420.prereq note: (Fourth-year standing or permission of the instructor.)
SCIE 420.prereq original: One of ASIC 200, ASIC 220, APBI 260, APBI 265, ARCL 309, BIOL 230, CHEM 301, CHEM 302, CHEM 341, CIVL 200, CONS 330, ECON 210, ENDS 221, ENVR 200, ENVR 300, EOSC 270, EOSC 340, FRST 100, GEOG 211, GEOG 310, HIST 106, ISCI 360, ISCI 361, LAW  386, LFS  250, PHYS 333, POLI 351, PSYC 321, SCIE 120. (Fourth-year standing or permission of the instructor.)

SEAL 440.longname: Supervised Study in Southeast Asian Languages

SLAV 307.description: Films and translated literature by Slavic writers with emphasis on the interaction between politics and literature.
SLAV 307.longname: Literature and Film in Eastern Europe

SOAL 440.longname: Supervised Study in South Asian Languages

SOCI 100.description: Introduction to problems in the analysis of social structures and processes. Basic sociological concepts will be introduced and their application demonstrated in various areas of sociology. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 100 or both SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

SOCI 101.description: Culture, identity, social interaction, relationships and socialization. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 101 or SOCI 100.

SOCI 102.description: Inequality, institutions, social structure and social change. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 102 or SOCI 100.

SOCI 200.description: An introduction to contemporary family forms and relations.

SOCI 201.description: An introduction to the study of the relations between ethnic groups and of the interplay between ethnicity and other social factors.

SOCI 210.description: Descriptive and analytic survey of such features as demographic characteristics, class structure, ethnicity, and regional variation in Canadian society as a basis for understanding current social issues.

SOCI 217.description: Introduction to research designs and methodologies.
SOCI 217.prereq original: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.

SOCI 220.description: Sociological perspective of Indigenous peoples and issues both internationally and within Canada.

SOCI 240.description: A general introduction to research on social interaction, with an emphasis on group (as opposed to individual) processes and behaviour. Topics include: status, power and prestige, distributive justice, marginality and social control, authority relations, and group structure and membership, all to be studied in the context of a variety of groups (such as families, formal organizations, communities and friendship groups) and cultures.

SOCI 250.description: Crime as a social phenomenon, with emphasis on the changing definitions of crime in relation to social and political change in Canadian and other societies. The scope and nature of the crime problem, the growth of criminology as a science and profession, and relationships between components of state criminal justice systems.

SOCI 260.description: The social forces responsible for changing patterns of technological innovation and work organization in modern industrial societies. Emphasis on the organization of work and the labour force.

SOCI 285.description: The concepts of citizenship, identity, and human rights as social processes shaping individuals and communities (both local and global).

SOCI 301.description: Processes of social change in the Third World and other developing countries. Major themes stress the relationship between urbanization and industrialization; modernization and ethnic conflict; imperialism, neo-colonialism, and foreign aid; and intra-national modernization problems such as regional underdevelopment in industrial societies.

SOCI 302.description: A critical examination of classical and contemporary theories and research evidence concerning ethnic and racial inequality at the societal and interpersonal levels.

SOCI 303.description: Sociological approaches to the movement of peoples and its impact over time.

SOCI 310.description: Social organization of Canadian society: relationships between social institutions and social processes (e.g., economics, education, family, law, media, and politics); including issues of ancestry, ethnicity, gender, region, and social class.

SOCI 312.description: The nature of gender relations, their social and cultural expression, and theories of gender inequality.

SOCI 320.description: An examination of diversity within and between families and of diverse family forms.
SOCI 320.prereq original: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.

SOCI 324.description: Individuals and families through the life course.
SOCI 324.prereq original: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.

SOCI 328.description: The testing of sociological theories using quantitative data analysis techniques on numerical data from social surveys, experiments and official statistics. SOCI 328 excludes credit for a number of other statistics courses in various departments. Please consult the Science Credit Exclusion List (www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414) before registering.

SOCI 342.description: The structure and culture of consuming and consumption.

SOCI 352.description: The meaning of work and leisure. Properties of work organization: division of labour and specialization; technology and working knowledge; means of coordinating work, such as cooperation, authority, and exchange. Research problems concerning work in households, offices, and industry, division of labour by gender, industrial democracy and the relation of work and social inequality.

SOCI 354.description: Study of the organization of human communities; a focus upon collective activities including family, work, neighbourhood, and formal and informal networks.

SOCI 360.description: Sociological perspectives on property, resource industries (such as agriculture, fishing, forestry and mining), resource development, and resource communities. May also include examination of social aspects of resource development in the Third World.

SOCI 361.description: Tendencies toward equality and inequality; manifestations of inequality (occupation, education, gender, ethnicity, income, power) and their consequences; caste and class features of major stratification systems; theories of social class; stratification profile of contemporary industrial societies.

SOCI 364.description: Physical, social, and economic aspects of built environments, including housing and community planning.

SOCI 369.description: Historical and social construction of sexual identities, desires, communities, and politics in the twentieth century.
SOCI 369.prereq original: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.

SOCI 370.description: An examination of selected traditions, conceptual problems, and current topics in the field of sociological theory. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 370 or both SOCI 371, SOCI 372.
SOCI 370.longname: Sociological Theories: Classical and Contemporary Approaches

SOCI 371.description: An examination of selected traditions, conceptual problems and topics in the foundational theories of sociology. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 371 or SOCI 370.

SOCI 372.description: A survey of theories in contemporary sociology. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 372 or SOCI 370.

SOCI 380.description: Questionnaire design, interviewing, sampling, and analysis of survey data.
SOCI 380.prereq original: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102 and SOCI 217 and SOCI 328.

SOCI 381.description: Experimental methods in sociology integrating quantitative and qualitative approaches. Emphasis is on research design to inform policy and decision making.
SOCI 381.longname: Sociological Methods: Experimental and Mixed Methods
SOCI 381.prereq original: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102 and SOCI 217.

SOCI 382.description: Examination of the different traditions of qualitative sociological inquiry and the associated methodological features used to study the interpretive practices and meanings in the everyday lives of individuals.
SOCI 382.prereq original: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102 and SOCI 217.

SOCI 383.description: Methodological problems and research strategies associated with the interpretation of socio-historical data; contributions of classical and contemporary approaches to historical sociology and social history.
SOCI 383.prereq original: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102 and SOCI 217.

SOCI 384.description: Classic and contemporary sociological perspectives on health, illness, and health care.  Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 384 and SOCI 484.

SOCI 387.description: Social dimensions of the causes, consequences, regulation, and treatment of substance use from Canadian and international perspectives.

SOCI 414.description: The emergence of feminist theory, its relationship to sociology, and the major theoretical schools of thought. The social basis and development of feminist thought from critiques of scholarship and research to contemporary debates will be addressed.

SOCI 415.description: Theoretical approaches to the study of the family and family forms.
SOCI 415.prereq original: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.

SOCI 416.description: An in-depth examination of selected sociological theories. Consult the department for this year's offerings.

SOCI 418.description: Primary emphasis on applications of statistical techniques to data in Sociology.
SOCI 418.prereq original: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102 and SOCI 328.

SOCI 420.description: Sociological approaches to the study of environmental conflicts, issues, movements, impact of changing technology, economic development on the environment.

SOCI 423.description: Cultural, economic, and political aspects of food production and consumption, including connections to class, ethnicity, and gender.  Food-related social movements will be included.

SOCI 425.description: Demographic, behavioural, and organizational aspects of urban structures and of urbanization in different societies and periods.

SOCI 433.description: General reading and/or a research undertaking, with the agreement, and under the supervision, of a Department faculty member selected by the student.
SOCI 433.prereq original: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102. (And permission of the Department.)

SOCI 435.description: International field placement normally for eight to ten weeks; pre-departure seminars (eight to twelve seminars or equivalent) with student presentation seminars upon return from the field.

SOCI 440.description: Analysis of economic actions and institutions using the concepts and methods of sociology.

SOCI 441.description: The study of family in social and economic contexts. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 441 and FMST 440.
SOCI 441.prereq original: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.

SOCI 442.description: The effect of combining family and work roles. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 442 and FMST 442.
SOCI 442.prereq original: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.

SOCI 449.description: Requires the presentation of at least one research paper. Restricted to students in the Sociology Honours program.

SOCI 464.description: A study of the sources, stages, and effects of social movements in developing and modernized societies.

SOCI 465.description: An examination of the arts as social practices from the standpoint of the relationships among artists, critics, patrons, and public; and the social institutions through which these relationships are structured.

SOCI 473.description: A sociological approach to the meaning of mental illness; the organization of psychiatric treatment; problems in the explanation of the distribution of mental illness in a population.

SOCI 479.description: Relationships between social phenomena (e.g., personal beliefs, lifestyle practices, social support, socio-economic status, social class, gender, and ethnicity) and the health of human populations.

SOCI 490.description: Current social topics in Chinese society; perspectives on gender, inequality, culture, and social relations.

SOCI 495.description: An intensive examination of selected topics in Sociology. Consult the department for this year's offerings.

SOWK 200.description: An introduction to the perspectives, concepts and theoretical foundations of social welfare, including an analysis of the institutional structures of social welfare in the modern state.

SOWK 201.description: An introduction to the knowledge, skills and values of social work practice in its many forms, emphasizing different ways of understanding the context of social and personal problems.

SOWK 305.description: An examination of the foundation, knowledge and competencies underlying generalist social work practice. Enrolment is limited to students in the B.S.W. program.

SOWK 310.description: Communication theory and interviewing skills and their application to the Social Work interview.

SOWK 315.description: A supervised practicum in an assigned social service, two days a week throughout the program year. Limited to students in the B.S.W. program. This course will be graded Pass/Fail.

SOWK 316.description: Integrates students' learning from field, practice, policy and theory courses for the purposes of professional development.
SOWK 316.longname: Integrative Seminar in Social Work Theory, Policy and Practice

SOWK 320.description: Introduction to theory and conduct of social research as applied to social welfare and social work practice. The focus is on development of social work research questions and design of studies. Enrolment is limited to students in the B.S.W. program, except by permission of the school.

SOWK 335.description: Theoretical considerations of relevance to social work practice.
SOWK 335.longname: Social Analysis for Social Work Practice

SOWK 337.description: Issues and problems inherent in practising social work in diverse cultural settings.
SOWK 337.longname: Culture and Race in Social Work Practice

SOWK 400.description: Analysis of race, gender, class and culture as factors in the distribution and delivery of Canadian social benefits and social services.

SOWK 405.description: This course examines the principles of optimal social work process with individuals, small groups, families and larger collectivities.

SOWK 415.description: A supervised practicum in an assigned social service, two days a week throughout the program year. Enrolment is limited to students in the B.S.W. program. This course will be graded Pass/Fail.

SOWK 416.description: Development of professional judgement, evaluation, and self-evaluation in practice.
SOWK 416.longname: Advanced Integrative Seminar in Social Work Theory, Policy and Practice
SOWK 416.shortname: ADV INT SEM IN SW TH

SOWK 425.description: Contemporary social issues facing First Nations peoples and communities examined in the context of the history of Euro-Canadian/First Nations relations; the impact of Euro-Canadian institutions upon First Nations peoples; implications for social policy and social work practice.

SOWK 430.description: Lectures, seminars and/or individual tutorials to develop knowledge and skills in relation to a defined theory, policy or practice problem or client population. Enrolment is limited to students in the B.S.W. program, except by permission of the School.

SOWK 440.description: A series of seminars offered during the final term of studies which address salient issues in social policy and social work practice and draw upon combined knowledge from social work and related disciplines.

SOWK 441.description: The ways in which the familial, physical, and social environment effects the life structures, opportunities and outcomes of epigenetic developmental processes.

SOWK 442.description: Covers the statutory bases and practices associated with the continuum of child welfare services from prevention through permanency planning.
SOWK 442.longname: Policy and Practice in Child Welfare
SOWK 442.prereq original: SOWK 441. (or another course in child development.)

SOWK 450.description: Online course providing overview of social work services to persons with a mental illness.
SOWK 450.longname: Social Work Practice in Community Mental Health

SOWK 451.description: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course covers the skills, knowledge, roles, and issues involved with working successfully in interprofessional health and human service teams. Intended for upper division students in any health and human service program. Offered as IHHS 400 prior to September 2015. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 451 or IHHS 400.

SOWK 453.description: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course considers how health and human service professionals can effectively practice with people with disabilities from a social justice perspective. Social and personal context and practice responses are examined. Offered as IHHS 407 prior to September 2015. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 453 or IHHS 407.

SPAN 101.description: Fundamentals of the Spanish language; speaking and writing on everyday activities and future plans in the context of common tasks and situations, including interactive communication, grammatical explanations, and cultural awareness.

SPAN 102.description: Speaking and writing on past events, and expressing desires and wishes in the context of common situations, including interactive communication, grammatical explanations, and cultural awareness.

SPAN 201.description: Reviews the fundamentals of the Spanish language, and introduces more complex structures; listening, speaking, writing, and reading on a range of situations related to everyday life and Hispanic culture.

SPAN 202.description: Expands on the fundamentals of the Spanish language, and presents more complex structures in a variety of tenses and modes; interacting through discussions and gaining cultural awareness through literature and film.

SPAN 206.description: Emphasizes communication skills through discussion, debate, and presentations; developing oral fluency and listening comprehension, through discussion of written texts and films. May include experiential learning projects involving native speakers from the Hispanic community.

SPAN 207.description: Builds on communication skills through discussion, debate, and presentations; exploration of cultural topics through discussion of written texts and other media. May include experiential learning projects involving native speakers from the Hispanic community.

SPAN 221.description: Major texts, authors, periods, and genres of Hispanic literature; key concepts, terminology, and practices of literary analysis that serve as a foundation for higher-level Spanish literature courses.

SPAN 280.description: Concepts, theories, and practice of protest, revolt, and revolution in the Hispanic world, highlighting the intersection of politics and culture through novels, poetry, letters, diaries, and/or historical accounts of specific revolutionary uprisings.

SPAN 301.description: Advanced grammar structures in context, lexical repertoire, fluency and cultural awareness to broaden and develop language skills.

SPAN 302.description: Advanced grammar structures in context; students expand lexical repertoire, and gain fluency and flexibility as they deepen cultural awareness through reading, listening, discussion, and writing.

SPAN 309.description: Language of international commerce through real world business practices in the Hispanic world; key issues concerning business practices, engaging with real-world materials, and interacting with professionals specializing in trade with the Hispanic world.
SPAN 309.longname: Business Spanish of International Trade in the Hispanic World (in Spanish)
SPAN 309.prereq note: (Or successful completion of a language placement exam or an assessment interview.)
SPAN 309.prereq original: One of SPAN 207, SPAN 302. (Or successful completion of a language placement exam or an assessment interview.)

SPAN 321.description: Conservation and progress on the Iberian Peninsula, from the Middle Ages to the present. Includes the first modern European state and its diverse cultures.
SPAN 321.longname: Tradition and Diversity in Spanish History and Culture
SPAN 321.prereq note: (Or successful completion of a language placement exam or an assessment interview.)
SPAN 321.prereq original: One of SPAN 202, SPAN 207. (Or successful completion of a language placement exam or an assessment interview.)

SPAN 357.description: Tradition, faith, conflict, prosperity, and decadence in literature and everyday life from the Middle Ages to 1700.
SPAN 357.longname: The Golden Age of Peninsular Literature and Culture
SPAN 357.prereq note: (Or successful completion of a language placement exam or an assessment interview.)
SPAN 357.prereq original: SPAN 221. (Or successful completion of a language placement exam or an assessment interview.)

SPAN 358.description: Modern Spanish literature and culture, from Empire to the European Union. Includes Romanticism, Modernism, Republicanism, and Separatism.
SPAN 358.longname: Divergent Visions: Peninsular Literature and Culture since 1700
SPAN 358.prereq note: (Or successful completion of a language placement exam or an assessment interview.)
SPAN 358.prereq original: SPAN 221. (Or successful completion of a language placement exam or an assessment interview.)

SPAN 364.description: Spanish colonialism in the Americas from the Conquest to the 1820's and the dawn of Independence. Includes coloniality, hybridity, subalternity, and autonomy.
SPAN 364.longname: Colonial Encounters in Spanish-American Literature and Culture
SPAN 364.prereq note: (Or successful completion of a language placement exam or an assessment interview.)
SPAN 364.prereq original: SPAN 221. (Or successful completion of a language placement exam or an assessment interview.)

SPAN 365.description: Literary engagements with modernity in the Spanish Americas, from the 1820's to the present. Includes civilization, progress, politicization, and violence.
SPAN 365.longname: Modern Magics: Spanish-American Literature and Culture since the 1820s
SPAN 365.prereq note: (Or successful completion of a language placement exam or an assessment interview.)
SPAN 365.prereq original: SPAN 221. (Or successful completion of a language placement exam or an assessment interview.)

SPAN 401.description: Purpose, practice, and methodologies of translation from Spanish into English and back. Includes translation theory, translation from a variety of sources (i.e. literary, journalistic, legal, technical).
SPAN 401.prereq note: (Or successful completion of a language placement exam or an assessment interview.)
SPAN 401.prereq original: SPAN 302. (Or successful completion of a language placement exam or an assessment interview.)

SPAN 402.description: Developing linguistic proficiency and effective and accurate communication in both spoken and written Spanish. Includes close reading of texts, advanced written composition, cross-cultural analysis, and conversational skills.

SPAN 406.description: Gender and sexuality in Spain and Latin America.
SPAN 406.longname: Breaking the Mold: Gender Representation(s) in Hispanic Literature and Culture
SPAN 406.prereq note: (Or successful completion of a language placement exam or an assessment interview.)
SPAN 406.prereq original: SPAN 221. (Or successful completion of a language placement exam or an assessment interview.)

SPAN 420.description: Selected areas of study relating to sixteenth- and seventeenth-century Spain. Consult the Department for this year's offerings.
SPAN 420.longname: Ascent and Decline: Topics in Golden-Age Peninsular Literature and Culture
SPAN 420.prereq note: (Or successful completion of a language placement exam or an assessment interview.)
SPAN 420.prereq original: SPAN 221. (Or successful completion of a language placement exam or an assessment interview.)

SPAN 495.description: Theories and methodologies of the discipline. Consult the Department for this year's offering.
SPAN 495.longname: Research Intensive Seminar in Hispanic Literature and Culture
SPAN 495.prereq note: (Or successful completion of a language placement exam or an assessment interview.)
SPAN 495.prereq original: SPAN 221. (Or successful completion of a language placement exam or an assessment interview.)

SPPH 300.description: This is a tutored, web based Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course on planning/preparing for work in a developing country. Causes of ill health amongst populations living in poverty; analysis of available solutions. Health Science background not essential. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 300 or IHHS 300.

SPPH 301.description: The Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course covers the idea of "population health," and the implementation and evaluation of programs or policies to improve health. Open to all students. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 200 or IHHS 200.
SPPH 301.longname: Understanding the Sociocultural Determinants of the Health of Populations

SPPH 302.description: Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 302 or IHHS 302.
SPPH 302.longname: Topics in Health Informatics for Health/Life Sciences Students

SPPH 381.description: By seminar and directed readings, certain topics of current interest are explored in depth.

SPPH 400.description: Planned collection, numeric and graphic summarization, and elementary statistical analysis of data. Examples primarily from health sciences illustrate standard techniques for parametric and non-parametric hypothesis testing; regression and correlation; contingency tables. Also randomization, "blindfolding" and other specifically biomedical topics in statistics. Class size may be limited.
SPPH 400.prereq note: (Ability to use high school Algebra and simple graphs.)
SPPH 400.prereq original: (Ability to use high school Algebra and simple graphs.)

SPPH 410.description: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course promotes collaborating interprofessionally. Each student team will identify and research a critical public health issue, and develop a detailed practical and effective intervention. Intended for students in health and human service programs. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 410 or IHHS 410.
SPPH 410.longname: Improving Public Health: An Interprofessional Approach to Designing and Implementing Effective Interventions

SPPH 411.description: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course covers violence in families across the lifespan. Particular emphasis on intersections of race, class, and gender; the long-term impact of childhood exposure to violence; and prevention-focused initiatives. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 411 or IHHS 411.

SPPH 481.description: Selected topics will vary.  Multiple versions may be taken. This course takes an interprofessional approach and population/public health perspective in addressing current issues in healthcare and health-related fields.
SPPH 481.longname: Special Topics in Population and Public Health

STAT 200.description: Classical, nonparametric, and robust inferences about means, variances, and analysis of variance, using computers. Emphasis on problem formulation, assumptions, and interpretation. See the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
STAT 200.prereq original: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001.

STAT 203.description: Organizing, displaying and summarizing data. Inference estimation and testing for elementary probability models. Not for credit towards a B.Sc. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section in the Calendar.)

STAT 241.description: Probability models, random variables and vectors, estimation, testing, regression, analysis of variance, goodness of fit, quality control. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section of the Calendar).
STAT 241.prereq original: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001.

STAT 251.description: Probability, discrete and continuous random variables, joint probability distributions, estimation, hypothesis testing, regression, analysis of variance, goodness of fit. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section of the Calendar).
STAT 251.prereq original: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001.

STAT 300.description: Further topics in statistical inference, including parametric and non-parametric methods, goodness-of-fit methods, analysis of variance and covariance, regression analysis, categorical data analysis, experimental designs, time series, model fitting, and statistical computing.
STAT 300.prereq original: One of STAT 200, STAT 241, STAT 251, BIOL 300, COMM 291, ECON 325, ECON 327, FRST 231, PSYC 218, PSYC 278, PSYC 366.

STAT 302.description: Basic notions of probability, random variables, expectation and conditional expectation, limit theorems. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section in the Calendar.)
STAT 302.prereq original: One of MATH 200, MATH 226, MATH 217, MATH 253, MATH 263.

STAT 305.description: Review of probability theory. Sampling distribution theory, large sample theory and methods of estimation and hypothesis testing, including maximum likelihood estimation, likelihood ratio testing and confidence interval construction.
STAT 305.prereq note: (The Department recommends that students meet the prerequisite through option (a). Note there is credit exclusion between MATH 302, STAT 302 and STAT 241, STAT 251.)
STAT 305.prereq original: Either (a) one of STAT 200, BIOL 300, STAT 241, STAT 251, COMM 291, ECON 325, FRST 231, PSYC 218, PSYC 366 and one of MATH 302, STAT 302;  or (b) a score of 65% or higher in one of MATH 302, STAT 302. (The Department recommends that students meet the prerequisite through option (a). Note there is credit exclusion between MATH 302, STAT 302 and STAT 241, STAT 251.)

STAT 306.description: Modeling a response (output) variable as a function of several explanatory (input) variables:  multiple regression for a continuous response, logistic regression for a binary response, and log-linear models for count data.  Finding low-dimensional structure:  principal components analysis.  Cluster analysis.  (Consult the Credit Exclusion List within the Faculty of Science section in the Calendar).
STAT 306.prereq original: One of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223 and one of STAT 200, STAT 241, STAT 251, STAT 300, BIOL 300, COMM 291, ECON 325, ECON 327, FRST 231, PSYC 218, PSYC 278, PSYC 366 and one of MATH 302, STAT 302.

STAT 321.description: Stochastic behaviour of signals and systems (e.g., communication systems); discrete and continuous probability; random processes; modeling and identification of linear time-invariant systems; binary hypothesis testing and decision making.
STAT 321.prereq note: (STAT 305 may be taken concurrently, with registration assistance from Statistics Student Services.)
STAT 321.prereq original: One of EECE 269, ELEC 221, STAT 305. (STAT 305 may be taken concurrently, with registration assistance from Statistics Student Services.)

STAT 344.description: Planning and practice of sample surveys. Random sampling, bias and variance, unequal probability sampling, systematic, multistage and stratified sampling, ratio and regression estimators, post-stratification, establishing a frame, pretesting, pilot studies, nonresponse and additional topics.
STAT 344.prereq original: One of STAT 200, STAT 241, STAT 251, BIOL 300, COMM 291, ECON 325, ECON 327, FRST 231, PSYC 218, PSYC 278, PSYC 366.

STAT 398.description: Work experience in an industrial research setting. Normally taken during Winter Session of third year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Statistics.
STAT 398.prereq note: (Registration in Statistics Honours or Major Program.)
STAT 398.prereq original: (Registration in Statistics Honours or Major Program.)

STAT 399.description: Work experience in an industrial research setting. Normally taken during Summer Session following third year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Statistics.

STAT 404.description: Theory and application of analysis of variance for standard experimental designs, including blocked, nested, factorial and split plot designs. Fixed and random effects, multiple comparisons, analysis of covariance. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section in the Calendar).

STAT 406.description: Flexible, data-adaptive methods for regression and classification models; regression smoothers; penalty methods; assessing accuracy of prediction; model selection; robustness; classification and regression trees; nearest-neighbour methods; neural networks; model averaging and ensembles; computational time and visualization for large data sets.

STAT 443.description: Trend and seasonality, autocorrelation, stationarity, stochastic models, exponential smoothing, Holt-Winters methods, Box-Jenkins approach, frequency domain analysis.
STAT 443.prereq original: One of MATH 302, MATH 318, STAT 302 and one of STAT 200, ECON 325.

STAT 447.description: Students should consult the Statistics Department for the particular topics offered in a given year.
STAT 447.prereq original: STAT305  (Permission of the instructor is required.)

STAT 450.description: Readings and projects in areas of current statistical application including environmental science, industrial statistics, official statistics, actuarial statistics, and medical statistics.

STAT 460.description: A detailed theoretical development. Statistical models, exponential families, sufficiency, completeness, and detailed properties of point estimation. Intended for Honours students.

STAT 461.description: Detailed development of the theory of testing hypotheses and confidence regions, Bayesian models and inference, elements of decision theory and additional topics. Intended for Honours students.

STAT 498.description: Work experience in an industrial research setting. Normally taken during Summer Session following fourth year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Statistics.

STAT 499.description: Work experience in an industrial research setting. Normally taken during Term 1 of Winter Session of fifth year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Statistics.

THTR 120.description: Theory and practice of the theatrical arts. Attendance at plays is required.

THTR 150.description: Foundation study of production technologies for the performing arts.

THTR 205.longname: Graphics for Theatre and Film Design

THTR 210.description: The Anatomy of Drama: Its history, aesthetic principles, performative potential.

THTR 211.description: Topics in comparative drama; drama and the other performing arts; dramaturgy.

THTR 245.description: Basic methods of interpreting dramatic texts and analyzing plays in performance. The plays presented on the Frederic Wood Stage will be studied in this course.

THTR 250.description: The construction and execution of scenery, costumes, properties, lighting, and sound for the stage.

THTR 271.description: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students. An audition is required.

THTR 272.description: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students.

THTR 273.description: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students. An audition is required.

THTR 274.description: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students.

THTR 301.description: Artistic, decorative, cultural, and social contexts of selected theatrical genres and periods.

THTR 305.description: Principles and practice of scenery design for the performing arts.

THTR 306.description: Principles and practice of costume design for the performing arts.

THTR 307.description: The optical, distribution, and control systems used in stage lighting design.

THTR 308.description: Audio design and production for theatre and other performance forms.

THTR 310.description: The basic principles of dramaturgy and theory of performance. Historical and contemporary writing on dramatic theory and criticism and their relation to theatrical practice.

THTR 317.prereq original: One of THTR 130, THTR 230 and THTR 299.

THTR 320.description: Core concepts in world theatre history and the development of theatre prior to the nineteenth century.

THTR 339.description: Study and practice of processes and forms used to create ensemble performance.

THTR 340.description: Open to all students in third year and above.

THTR 352.description: Media, techniques, and textural treatments used in scene painting.

THTR 354.description: Principles and procedures of stage management: organizations, systems, and operations.

THTR 356.description: Advanced assembly and specialized construction methods for producing costume for stage and screen.

THTR 371.description: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students.
THTR 371.prereq original: All of THTR 271, THTR 272, THTR 273, THTR 274.

THTR 372.description: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students.

THTR 373.description: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students.
THTR 373.longname: Intermediate Voice, Speech, and Movement I
THTR 373.prereq original: All of THTR 271, THTR 272, THTR 273, THTR 274.

THTR 374.description: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students.
THTR 374.longname: Intermediate Voice, Speech, and Movement II

THTR 391.description: Open only to  B.F.A. Acting students.
THTR 391.prereq original: All of THTR 271, THTR 272, THTR 273, THTR 274.

THTR 399.coreq original: One of THTR 305, THTR 306, THTR 307, THTR 308, THTR 350, THTR 352, THTR 354, THTR 356.
THTR 399.description: Assigned projects in theatre design and production.

THTR 405.description: Exploration of complex scenery design and development of design portfolio.

THTR 406.description: Complex problems and selected historical studies in costume design.

THTR 407.description: Complex design and advanced technologies in stage lighting and scenography.

THTR 408.description: Topics will vary from year to year. Consent of Department required.
THTR 408.longname: Advanced Study in Design and Scenography

THTR 410.description: Advanced problems in dramaturgy, both in a historical and a contemporary context.

THTR 417.prereq note: (Permission of the instructor is required for admission to this course.)
THTR 417.prereq original: THTR 317. (Permission of the instructor is required for admission to this course.)

THTR 420.description: Key movements in world theatre history from the nineteenth century to the present.

THTR 439.description: Ensemble creation culminating in the presentation of a theatrical work. Permission of the instructor is required.

THTR 440.description: An examination in depth of a selected area of theatre history, theory or practice. Topics will change from year to year. May be repeated for credit when topics differ.
THTR 440.prereq note: (6 credits of THTR at the 300-level or above.)
THTR 440.prereq original: (6 credits of THTR at the 300-level or above.)

THTR 443.description: A course dealing with women's involvement in and contribution to various aspects of Theatre and/or Film Topics will change from year to year.

THTR 448.longname: Directed Studies in Theatre Theory and Practice

THTR 450.description: Technical direction; complex techniques and problems in scenery production.

THTR 452.description: Study of selected scene painting styles.

THTR 454.description: Production and theatre management with emphasis on budgeting, publicity, scheduling, press relations, special events, legal issues, season selection, resumes and interpersonal skills.

THTR 456.description: Pattern development and cutting for costume for stage and screen using flat pattern and draping.

THTR 469.description: Group projects and workshops with students majoring in other creative arts.

THTR 471.prereq original: All of THTR 371, THTR 372, THTR 373, THTR 374, THTR 391.

THTR 472.description: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students.

THTR 473.description: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students.
THTR 473.prereq original: Three of THTR 371, THTR 372, THTR 373, THTR 374, THTR 391.

THTR 474.description: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students.

THTR 491.description: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students.
THTR 491.prereq original: Three of THTR 371, THTR 372, THTR 373, THTR 374, THTR 391.

THTR 499.coreq original: One of THTR 405, THTR 406, THTR 407, THTR 408, THTR 450, THTR 452, THTR 454, THTR 456, THTR 470.
THTR 499.description: Assigned projects in Theatre or Film design and production.

TIBT 100.description: Concepts, grammar, syntax of spoken and written Tibetan for beginners. Also covers aspects of Tibetan worldview.

TIBT 101.description: Focus on grammar, syntax, and structures to improve comprehension and communication skills. Also covers aspects of Tibetan worldview.

UFOR 100.description: Roles played by urban forestry and greenspace systems in a rapidly changing world; topics include urban ecology, urban forest conservation, urban forest management, climate change, society and human well-being, design and planning, urban/rural interface issues, and urban forest policy.

UFOR 101.description: Overview of urban forest resources: structure and composition, extent, and ecosystem services and benefits provided; introduces methods and tools for urban forest inventory, monitoring, and assessment, and how they are integrated into the planning and management of urban forests.

UFOR 200.description: Basic relationships between urban residentsï¿½ mental and physical well-being and their urban forest environment.

UFOR 201.description: Basic concepts of landscape design as it relates to urban forestry.

UFOR 300.description: Sustainable practice within the arboricultural discipline with emphasis on a comprehensive understanding of techniques and equipment used in a range of arboricultural operations.

UFOR 316.description: Culture and identification of landscape materials with emphasis on woody plants. Elementary principles of landscape composition. Suitable for students of other faculties and departments interested in landscape materials and their uses, but priority given to Agroecology and Landscape Architecture students. Credits toward the completion of the Bachelor of Urban Forestry will be granted for only one of LARC 316 or UFOR 316.

UFOR 400.description: Development of field skills, professional judgment, critical reflection, and integration of theory, practice, and policy. Offered at Malcolm Knapp Research Forest over a 7-day period in April.
UFOR 400.prereq note: (And third year standing in the B.U.F. program.)
UFOR 400.prereq original: UFOR 200. (And third year standing in the B.U.F. program.)

UFOR 401.description: Integration of biophysical and socio-economic components of urban greenspace management and planning through within a collaborative holistic group project linked to a real-world urban forestry situation.
UFOR 401.prereq note: (And fourth year standing in the B.U.F. program.)
UFOR 401.prereq original: All of UFOR 300, UFOR 400. (And fourth year standing in the B.U.F. program.)

UFOR 402.description: The administrative, legal, policy, and business environments for urban forestry governance, management, and planning.
UFOR 402.longname: Urban Forestry Administration, Policy and Law

UFOR 403.description: Ecological principles relevant to restoration of ecosystems are applied to the restoration of several types of ecosystems.
UFOR 403.prereq original: One of FRST 201, BIOL 230. (And third year standing)

UFOR 449.description: In special cases and with the approval of the instructor concerned, a student may carry out directed studies on a specific topic/problems in Urban Forestry and related greenspace planning, management, or governance.

UFOR 495.description: Urban centres can be designed and managed to contribute to biodiversity conservation commitments. Topics include designing human-dominated landscapes to promote biodiversity, the tools required, assessing outcomes, and the benefits and negatives of nature in the city.
UFOR 495.prereq original: One of FRST 200, BIOL 230. (or permission of the instructor.)

URST 200.description: An interdisciplinary introduction to the city in the context of contemporary globalization.  Analysis of urban patterns and processes from the theoretical perspectives of various disciplines and methodologies.

URST 400.description: A seminar for senior students who wish to explore some common topics of importance to urban studies from the viewpoints of several disciplines.

VANT 140.description: Sustained language support for linked content courses in International Program. Students develop strategies for self-directed learning.

VANT 148.description: Projects linked to topics explored in the UBC Vantage College International Program curricula.

VANT 150.description: Topics in sustainability, including the impact of technology on the environment and society, and fundamentals of engineering design. Restricted to students in the UBC Vantage College Engineering Stream.

VISA 101.description: Introduction to a broad range of contemporary studio practice. Intended for first year Bachelor of Fine Arts VISA students.

VISA 110.description: Foundation instruction in techniques and approaches to digital practice. The nature of digital technologies and their role in contemporary culture will be examined. (This course is open to all UBC students, regardless of prior experience.)

VISA 180.description: Drawing, painting, and related media in an introduction to studio practice. (This course is open to all UBC students, regardless of prior experience.)

VISA 183.description: Contemporary art practices, emphasizing the relationship between meanings and materials, art historical contexts and concepts, and non-traditional materials. (This course is open to all UBC students, regardless of prior experience.)
VISA 183.longname: Foundation Studio: Ideas as Practice I

VISA 210.description: Examination of current art practices and issues related to digital technologies and contemporary culture, with an emphasis on the theoretical conceptualization of digital artistic media.
VISA 210.prereq original: A score of 72% or higher in one of VISA 110, VISA 180, VISA 183.

VISA 220.description: Development of skills in drawing including life drawing. Introduction to the development of personal style and concepts.
VISA 220.prereq original: A score of 72% or higher in one of VISA 110, VISA 180, VISA 183.

VISA 230.description: Development of a variety of techniques and approaches to painting. Emphasis on developing a strong paint vocabulary as well as acquiring knowledge of historical and contemporary issues in painting.
VISA 230.prereq original: A score of 72% or higher in one of VISA 110, VISA 180, VISA 183.

VISA 240.description: Introduction to photography techniques and image-making. Emphasis on camera techniques and film and darkroom production. Only one of VISA 240 or VISA 241 may be used toward requirements for Major, Minor, or Honours programs in Visual Art.
VISA 240.prereq original: A score of 72% or higher in one of VISA 110, VISA 180, VISA 183.

VISA 241.description: Introduction to digital photography image creation in relation to contemporary art. Emphasis on digital camera use, file management, and digital print production.  Only one of VISA 240 or VISA 241 may be used toward requirements for Major, Minor, or Honours programs in Visual Art.
VISA 241.prereq original: A score of 72% or higher in one of VISA 110, VISA 180, VISA 183.

VISA 250.description: Visual print culture, and contemporary and historical technical print practices. Emphasis on hand-drawn intaglio, relief, screen and/or stencil printing, and graphic digital applications.
VISA 250.prereq original: A score of 72% or higher in one of VISA 110, VISA 180, VISA 183.

VISA 260.description: Contemporary sculpture practice and theory. Various sculpture materials and technologies including machinery use.
VISA 260.prereq original: A score of 72% or higher in one of VISA 110, VISA 180, VISA 183.

VISA 280.description: Development and history of contemporary art practice, with a focus on how artists realize and exchange ideas. Intended for second year BFA VISA students.
VISA 280.longname: Contemporary Art: Ideas as Practice II
VISA 280.prereq original: A score of 72% or higher in VISA 183.

VISA 310.description: Exploring issues and topics in interactive digital media and culture through the creation of critical contemporary art. Includes technical instruction with a focus on the development of individual and group projects.

VISA 311.description: Investigation of issues and topics in digital media and visual culture through the production of contemporary video art. Technical instruction in video manipulation software. Individual and/or group projects.

VISA 320.description: Investigation of drawing as a discipline in the context of contemporary art. Emphasis on expanding definitions of the drawing practice while focusing on technical and conceptual development.

VISA 321.description: Investigation of drawing as a discipline in the context of contemporary art and theory. Emphasis on self-directed projects in consultation with the instructor.

VISA 330.description: Development of techniques and personal style in relation to ideas. History and contemporary issues in painting will be introduced  to assist students in conceptualizing their painting practice.

VISA 331.description: Further investigation of painting in the context of contemporary art.  Emphasis on self directed projects in consultation with the instructor.

VISA 340.description: An investigation of approaches to photography and its meaning in the context of contemporary art. The term theme will be determined by the instructor. B & W, colour and digital production.

VISA 341.description: An investigation of contemporary photography production and approaches to the constructed image with emphasis on medium and large format camera use and studio lighting techniques.

VISA 350.description: Intaglio and relief print applications (i.e., etching, wood and/or lino cut, and collagraph) in combination with digital and photographic technologies, and drawing; discussion of contemporary and historical visual print culture.
VISA 350.longname: Intermediate Print Media I: Interdisciplinary Approaches to Image Production
VISA 350.prereq original: Either (a) VISA 250 or (b) one of VISA 290, VISA 283, VISA 284, FINA 290, FINA 283, FINA 284.

VISA 351.description: Screen printing and other print applications in combination with digital and photographic technologies, and drawing, explored within the context of contemporary art.
VISA 351.longname: Intermediate Print Media II: Interdisciplinary Approaches to Image Production
VISA 351.prereq original: Either(a) VISA 250 or (b) one of VISA 283, VISA 284, VISA 290, FINA 283, FINA 284, FINA 290.

VISA 352.description: Lithographic printing; suitable for students interested in drawing and print media interface in context of contemporary art; related digital and photographic technologies employed.
VISA 352.longname: Intermediate Print Media III: Interdisciplinary Approaches to Image Production
VISA 352.prereq original: Either (a) one of VISA 220, VISA 250 or (b) one of VISA 281, FINA 281, VISA 283, VISA 284, VISA 290, FINA 283, FINA 284, FINA 290.

VISA 361.description: Development of personal concerns in three-dimensional work. Emphasis on the integration of diverse materials and techniques.
VISA 361.prereq original: One of VISA 260, VISA 285, VISA 286, FINA 285, FINA 286.

VISA 370.description: Intermediate tutorial. Not offered every year.

VISA 380.description: A seminar in problems in contemporary art practice and related theory. Preference given to Visual Art students.

VISA 390.description: Seminar-based studio focusing on performance and actions in the field of contemporary art.
VISA 390.prereq note: (6 credits of 200-level VISA with an average of at least 72%.)
VISA 390.prereq original: (6 credits of 200-level VISA with an average of at least 72%.)

VISA 401.description: Research-based studio with thematic or disciplinary focus.  Intended for senior Visual Art undergraduate students.
VISA 401.prereq original: Three of VISA 310, VISA 311, VISA 320, VISA 321, VISA 330, VISA 331, VISA 340, VISA 341, VISA 350, VISA 351, VISA 360, VISA 361, VISA 370, VISA 390.

VISA 475.description: Exhibition course focusing on current curatorial practices and theories with an emphasis on contemporary visual art with the aim of preparing students to engage in the active organization of a large exhibition. Restricted to 4th year Majors in either VISA or ARTH, or permission of the instructor.

VISA 479.description: Advanced performance art practices and research methodologies.

VISA 480.description: Readings in art theory and criticism.

VISA 481.description: Readings in art theory and criticism.

VISA 490.description: Advanced work in contemporary and historical aspects of studio practice. Permission of instructor required. Not offered every year.
VISA 490.prereq note: (6 credits of 300-level VISA and 3 credits of 400-level VISA.)
VISA 490.prereq original: (6 credits of 300-level VISA and 3 credits of 400-level VISA.)

VISA 491.description: Advanced work in contemporary and historical aspects of studio practice. Permission of instructor required.
VISA 491.prereq note: (6 credits of 300-level VISA and 3 credits of 400-level VISA.)
VISA 491.prereq original: (6 credits of 300-level VISA and 3 credits of 400-level VISA.)

WOOD 120.description: Introduction to forestry, wood products industry, processes, products, markets and global trade policy issues affecting the wood industry. Not available for credit to students in the B.S.F. degree.
WOOD 120.longname: Introduction to Wood Products and Global Trade

WOOD 225.description: Strategies for thinking critically and writing effectively about topics that engage practitioners in Forestry, particularly in Wood Products Processing.  Planning, drafting and editing of professional-quality documents for specialists and other stakeholders. Developing oral presentation skills.

WOOD 244.description: Solving practical problems in the wood industry using computer-based mathematical tools including spreadsheets, visual basic programming and relational database systems.
WOOD 244.longname: Quantitative Methods in the Wood Industry
WOOD 244.prereq original: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121.

WOOD 245.description: Practical computer and problem solving cases taken from wood products manufacturing industrial applications.
WOOD 245.longname: Programming for Wood Products Manufacturing Applications

WOOD 249.description: Seminars on current forestry and wood products topics.
WOOD 249.longname: Contemporary Topics in Forestry and Wood Products

WOOD 271.description: Chemistry relating to wood and wood products: chemistry of lignin, cellulose, hemicelluloses, extractives, and biological degradation of lignocellulosics; wood pressure impregnation procedures.

WOOD 276.description: Introduction to the strength of materials with emphasis on the elastic properties and ultimate strength of wood and wood products.
WOOD 276.prereq original: One of PHYS 101, PHYS 117, PHYS 170 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121.

WOOD 280.description: Introduction to tree growth; macroscopic and microscopic anatomy and identification of softwoods and hardwoods; descriptions of cell wall ultra-structure, wood variability and wood quality.

WOOD 282.description: Wood-moisture relationships, transport phenomena, acoustical and electrical properties of wood. Effects of wood attributes at macro- and micro-levels on the strength properties of solid wood.

WOOD 290.description: Basic secondary wood products manufacturing. Focus on producing and joining lumber, edging, drilling, veneers and CNC equipment.

WOOD 292.description: Computer-aided graphics software used in the wood products sector.  Visualization of product designs and specifications in two and three dimensions.

WOOD 310.description: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term assignment required. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in Wood Products Processing.

WOOD 311.description: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term assignment required. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in Wood Products Processing.

WOOD 330.description: Use of industrial engineering concepts and methods to analyze and improve organizations, including operations strategy and competitiveness, quality control, work measurement, inventory management, linear programming, sensitivity analysis, transportation problems, and capacity planning.

WOOD 335.description: Modern techniques for improving quality in the workplace with particular emphasis on the forest products industry. Topics include quality control management, control charting, continuous improvement and analysis of variance techniques.

WOOD 356.description: Machines used for wood products manufacturing, design, maintenance, purchasing. Selection of components including drives, bearings, brakes, clutches, fasteners, springs.

WOOD 373.description: Introduction to structure and properties of polymers and wood finishes; chemistry of adhesives and preservatives.

WOOD 384.description: Introduction to primary log breakdown systems and lumber material flow in modern sawmills and planermills. Lumber drying equipment and methods.

WOOD 386.description: Beam analysis, shaft analysis, columns, stress/strain transformations, thin-walled pressure vessels, material strength failure, criteria, fatigue, design and sizing, ISO standards.

WOOD 400.description: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks fulltime.  Final work term assignment required. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in Wood Products Processing.

WOOD 412.description: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term assignment required. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in Wood Products Processing.

WOOD 430.description: Techniques for developing a plan,setting goals, and evaluating the impact of changes in the design, layout and operation of the factory with an emphasis on computer simulation.

WOOD 440.description: Use of engineering economics to evaluate investment proposals of an engineering nature, including decision making processes, time value of money, cash flow analysis, comparison methods, depreciation, replacement analysis, taxes, inflation and sensitivity analysis.

WOOD 449.description: In special cases and with the approval of the instructor concerned, a student may carry on directed studies of specific problems in wood products processing.
WOOD 449.longname: Directed Studies in Wood Products Processing

WOOD 461.description: Examination of globalization and its impact on sustainability, including social, economic, and environmental aspects.

WOOD 464.description: Introduction to polymeric coatings and finishes used in the wood products industry; surface preparation, application equipment and properties of various coatings; wood deterioration and its protection for external applications.

WOOD 465.description: Business management concepts common in the forest products industry including marketing, customer research, product development and design.

WOOD 474.description: Wood moisture, density and strength properties; manufacturing processes for major forest products.

WOOD 475.description: Elementary chemical, physical and mechanical properties of wood and their variations in relation to structure; identification by hand lens features; manufacture of lumber, pulp and composite wood products. Not available for credit to Wood Products Processing students.

WOOD 476.description: Design of timber structural elements using limit states design principles; joints and fasteners, sawn lumber and engineered wood products, light frame systems and shear walls.

WOOD 478.description: Building enclosure design considering heat and moisture transmission, air flow and ventilation, condensation, acoustics; roofing systems; diagnostic evaluations; fire protection.

WOOD 482.description: Introduction to computer assisted design and manufacturing with a focus on the fundamental issues of geometry and machine tools including an understanding of standard computer tools. Applications to secondary wood products manufacturing.

WOOD 485.description: The theory and practice of modern construction techniques used in the manufacture of furniture and cabinets.

WOOD 487.description: Physical, chemical and mechanical variables involved in adhesive bonding of composite wood products; characteristics of adhesives; plywood, composite wood panels, hardboard, medium density fibreboard, laminated wood and engineered lumber composites manufacturing processes; important physical and chemical properties of products.

WOOD 488.description: Introduction to wood products design, from the product idea to the production-ready design.
WOOD 488.longname: Wood Products Design and Development I

WOOD 491.description: Introduction to pneumatic and hydraulic power, design and selection of waste recycling systems, boilers, energy generation and environmental legislation.

WOOD 492.description: Applications of mathematical modeling, optimization, and simulation in forest planning and manufacturing; formulating models and interpreting results for decision support.

WOOD 493.description: A report (approved by a faculty supervisor and the Program Director) based on either a technical description of a study, an extension of the senior co-op report, a detailed literature review, a research-based project, or a guided independent study developed by the student.

WOOD 494.description: Wood cutting fundamentals, chip formation, cutting conditions, cutting edge maintenance, sawing, planing and molding, veneer cutting, chipping, turning.
WOOD 494.longname: Principles of Wood Cutting and Tooling

WOOD 499.description: Development of a wood products manufacturing start-up company.  Development of comprehensive business plan, marketing strategy, product design, equipment selection and justification, manufacturing plant layout, and economic analyses.
WOOD 499.prereq note: (and fourth-year standing in Wood Products Processing.)
WOOD 499.prereq original: All of WOOD 440, WOOD 465. (and fourth-year standing in Wood Products Processing.)

WRDS 150.description: Writing and reading in the social sciences and humanities, focusing on practices which the research disciplines share, and those which differentiate them. Credit will be granted for only one of WRDS 150 or ASTU 150.
WRDS 150.longname: Research and Writing in the Humanities and Social Sciences

WRDS 350.description: An advanced scholarly research and writing course that allows students to build on their existing knowledge of academic research and writing practices by studying specific features of scholarly writing relevant to their own interests and disciplines.
WRDS 350.prereq note: (Restricted to Faculty of Arts students with 3rd-year standing.)
WRDS 350.prereq original: (Restricted to Faculty of Arts students with 3rd-year standing.)

WRIT 098.longname: Preparation for University Writing and the LPI
